Did a search and I didn't find any owners' thread, so here goes..
 
 
 
 
Some links I found useful:
 
External workshops:
http://www.mycarforum.com/topic/2675115-independent-workshop-for-mercedes-benz/?hl=mercedes
 
 
 
Freebies that you can expect from Merc:
 
(with contributions from @heman75)
 
1. 3k service credit. anything more depend your bargain and model. E and above will be like 5k. A, B and C i think only 3k but can ask for more. i did it for my other car. usually within 500$more
2.. JS front back camera sure give
3. insurance some loyalty discount for next two year renewal.
4. 3D matt
5. solar film
6. some car essential package inclusive nano coat.
7. welcome pack.. laptop bag.
8. some amount of overtrade 
 
(feel free to add more to the list)

I have also found some tips and info useful from the sales reps:
 
- you can seek help in M'sia from C&C Malaysia, and claim the amount back if you are under warranty
 
- if you are under warranty, it's best to leave the car unmodified, for fear of voiding the warranty, but some have successfully done things like steering wheel, changed the HU etc
 
- you can add the Garmin GPS to the Audio 20 HU, Elebest does it, but I don't know if that voids the warranty. BTW, the Garmin system is not a touch screen one
 
- if you want to know the spare tire model no for the A/B/CLA class it's : 
16-inch space saver steel wheel (A24640026002000), spare wheel bag (A0005851195) and vehicle tool kit (B6685079128)
Keeping this page for model updates and links to reviews :)

this probably also applies to other makes, their in-house isn't that good when they take over your existing car.. even if it is also a merc.
if u have the time to wait, sell it on your own.

Freebies that you can expect from Merc:
 
 
1. 3k service credit. anything more depend your bargain and model. E and above will be like 5k. A, B and C i think only 3k but can ask for more. i did it for my other car. usually within 500$more

Also can ask mercedes benz shop voucher can get bags shirt etc

I have also found some tips and info useful from the sales reps:
 
- you can seek help in M'sia from C&C Malaysia, and claim the amount back if you are under warranty
 
- if you are under warranty, it's best to leave the car unmodified, for fear of voiding the warranty, but some have successfully done things like steering wheel, changed the HU etc
 
- you can add the Garmin GPS to the Audio 20 HU, Elebest does it, but I don't know if that voids the warranty. BTW, the Garmin system is not a touch screen one
 
- if you want to know the spare tire model no for the A/B/CLA class it's : 
16-inch space saver steel wheel (A24640026002000), spare wheel bag (A0005851195) and vehicle tool kit (B6685079128)
The Garmin GPS that I added to my Audio 20HU is a touch screen one, did it at C&C, crappy interface but it keeps the dashboard uncluttered.  The original Mercedes GPS in Europe, South Africa, Australia and a few other countries are however top notch.

Not really, modern engines especially the better ones comes with at least 2 fuel maps in their stock ECU.
 
Depending on the RON figure it detects (I don't think they do a direct analysis, probably a retrograde analysis of the engine detonation, emission data on the run), the timing can be advanced or retarded and thus generating different HP/Torque figure.
 
So if you are the sedate kind of driver, the lower RON petrol will be most cost efficient. If you are the zoom zoom kind, then the higher RON petrol might actually be more cost effective minus the smile on your face each time you take a nicely performed bend/sweeping curve.

Haha. Well performance wise, an upgrade from Ferrari.  
Although maybe not vis a vis M5. At least in a straight line.  My slightly tuned M5 (dynoed at 630 hp) was bloody fast, fastest I've ever driven, and I've driven some fast cars. 
 
Little acknowledged fact, but a stock M5 will take a stock GTR from a rolling start.  Standing start the AWD GTR has the advantage. But a godzilla killer in sedan form deserves real respect.
 
However the M5 is simply not very distinguished on the roads. And there are tons of fakes out there. 
 
Overall I'm much happier in the GT than in my F430. The latter attracted attention everywhere but I never liked that. The GT is largely stealthy but even so the car enthusiasts recognise it. I've had people in nicer cars - Porsches and tricked out Audis for example - taking pics of my GT. These are likely to be real hardcore car lovers. In contrast, the 430 got photographed by *everyone*. Even aunties recognise a Fallali. 
 
Plus of course newer tech (Bluetooth!!) and much better transmission in the  new car compared to Ferrari. Basically crunch time came when deciding whether to renew COE, and given the trade in offered by CnC (I lost no money), it was a no brainer to go for the new GT with total peace of mind.

this is good info.  I wonder if we could add an external battery to the camera to operate the camera during park mode.  Previously my Blackvue utilizes such a solution.

Agree that it's better sell it on your own...their recent offer trade in price was low and unattractive despite my car is a merc bought from them previously. I got much better quote from outside car dealers. 
 
On the contrary, I had a different experience with them.  I was offered a trade-in price that is over and above what Jaguar Land Rover and PML offered me for my Bimmer 5er that was previously bought from PML.
 
Having said that, I was purchasing the run-out W211 Edition E E200 so I'm sure C& C strategy was to throw in the usual `over-trade' to the used car price so that it makes it seem less painful that you did not `lose' so much on your trade-in car.  It sure work on me as I was already conditioned to the new car price as well as taking a significant hit on the trade in loss which is the usual case.  Despite that, it's still a significant of approximately $45k of `overtrade' and that's before adding the usual insurance, finance discounts, service credits, frills.
 
Let me explain:-
 
New Car E200 Published Price: 
$257k
 
Old 5er: 
1) Used Car Dealers selling equivalent model and age: $80-90k
2) Jaguar Land Rover Used Car Offer Price: $65k
3) PML Used Car Dealer Offer Price: $63k
4) C&C (Republic Auto) Offer Price: $115k (I know it's a ridiculous price coz it can't be higher than what Used Car Dealers are selling my 5er for)
 
So I guess it all boils down to how desperate C&C wants to clear stock.

Trivia for Mercedes-Benz enthusiasts or would-be enthusiasts.
 
Here's a demystifying of their engine model names.
 
 
Motorbezeichnung ist wie folgt verschlüsselt:M = Motor (Otto)Baureihe = 3 stelligDE = DirekteinspritzungHubraum = Deziliter (gerundet)A = AbgasturboladerL = Ladeluftkühlungred. = leistungsreduziert
 
In English;
 
 
The motor name is code as follows:M = engineSeries = 3 digitsDE = direct injectionDisplacement = deciliter (rounded)A = exhaust gas turbochargerL = charged air coolingred. = reduced performance

Interesting..... They actually will denote a defined engine...
 
Meaning for the same capacity,  a red coded engine can potentially be ecu flashed to the max tuned engine without change in hardware....  C200 - >C250 - >C300. 

 
Assuming the engine hardware is very similar, theoretically sounds possible.
It may possibly be though that red. engines are built to poorer tolerances and specifications and may fail to reliably produce the higher output.

Unreliable Merc engines?
No...

Unreliable Merc engines?
No... 

 
It's not a question of whether Mercedes engines are reliable in general, it's a question of whether red. spec engines are built to the same tolerances of non red. spec.
There is a reason why the practice of blueprinting exists. Finely building an engine with exact fits and what not can significantly increase its reliability and performance, just as mass production to wider variances will result in cheaper but potentially weaker engines.
 
But please note I am not saying the red. engines are proven to be different in hardware. I am just offering a theory that I believe should be taken into account before rushing to re-map a red. engine to higher model outputs.

Been looking around, and I can report back on where to find accessories:
 
For a brick and mortar shop options:
 
Autobacs:
- the biggest selection, you can touch, ask questions etc
 
NTUC:
surprisingly good
 
SGgarage, and a few others. Mod shops that also sell some kit that you can add on. 
 
For serious electrical mods;
 
Elebest:
 
Max does all kinds of stuff: GPS, keyless, etc
 
ONLINE:
 
Ah this is where the interesting stuff begins:
 
Amazon:
Amazing place where you can get stuff that suits all kinds of cars. And don't limit yourself to Amazon USA. For the Merc, which is German in origin, try search in Amazon UK and De. They may be cheaper, and offer more options. Things like car mats, wipers, replacement parts, and more.
 
Ebay:
A traditional source, and I might get my window visors from there. Made in USA and sells for the same price as the ones from ebay Malaysia.
 
Aliexpress:
A huge market place, and like Taobao, it offers many items, which are not just made in China. I got a console shelf that fits in the console box between the seats, plus some red control knobs. Do compare prices, and see if it's cheaper than Amazon and vice versa.
 
Taobao:
Another large market, but it's in Chinese and I am not too familiar. There are options to ship over, so one can consider that too.  
 
Will add more info when I explore more...

http://paultan.org/2016/10/31/mercedes-benz-reveals-first-details-of-new-engine-family-48v-mild-hybrid-and-electric-turbo/
 
 

Home » Cars » Mercedes-Benz reveals first details of new engine family – 48V, mild hybrid and electric turbo	Mercedes-Benz reveals first details of new engine family – 48V, mild hybrid and electric turboIn Cars, Mercedes-Benz, Technology / By Paul Tan /	31 October 2016 10:45 am/ 9 comments
 

Mercedes-Benz have unveiled the first details of the next generation engines at a Mercedes-Benz TecDay event. These engines, no matter how impressive they may sound, are not concepts, and will make debuts in production cars in 2017.
There’s love for both petrol and diesel engines from Mercedes-Benz, ranging from four-cylinder motors all the way to big V8s, although the latter does see some further shrinkage in terms of displacement. All engines are built around the 500cc per cylinder displacement concept so you have 2.0, 3.0 and 4.0 litre engines.
New M256 inline-six petrol engine

The rumours are true – Mercedes-Benz has abandoned the V6 in favour for the inline-6 configuration. But the inline-six layout isn’t all that’s new for the 3.0 litre M256 petrol engine.
The engine uses a 48V electrical system, which allows the entire ancillary system to be overhauled. For example, there is no longer any belt drive in front of the engine to power stuff like the water pump or aircond compressor – these are all electric items that are powered by the 48V system now, so they can be positioned elsewhere in the engine bay.
This results in shorter installation space requirements. Since the inline-six is narrower than V6, the ancillary systems are positioned on the left and right of the engine.
The engine is turbocharged but also has a 48V-powered electric auxiliary compressor (eZV, or electric turbo) to eliminate turbo lag. The starter motor has also been replaced with an Integrated Starter-Generator (ISG) installed in between the engine and the transmission that can provide a 15 kW boost to the engine.
Total output for the engine can go up to over 408 horsepower and over 500 Nm, while CO2 emissions have reduced by about 15 percent compared to the outgoing V6 engine.
The engine also includes a particulate filter in the exhaust system, which is something you usually see only on diesel engines. For petrol engine particulate filters, Mercedes-Benz is using cordierite, instead of silicon carbide which it uses for diesel particulate filters.
This engine will debut with the W222 S-Class facelift next year.
New OM656 inline-six diesel engine

Lovers of big diesel engines will be able to enjoy more power – the OM656 is now expected to do 313 horsepower up from 258 horsepower of the outgoing big diesel, while consumption is reduced by seven percent.
The OM656 uses stepped-bowl combustion, two-stage exhaust turbocharging, and a new feature for Mercedes-Benz diesel engines – CAMTRONIC variable valve timing.
New M176 V8 bi-turbo petrol engine

As expected, Mercedes-Benz’s non-AMG V8 is now 4.0 litres, following the direction set by AMG’s new V8 engine. From its 3,982cc displacement, peak horsepower is 476 hp (up from 455 hp) with peak torque of 700 Nm kicking in from 2,000 rpm.
The closed deck V8 has cylinder deactivation, which allows it to run on four cylinders during light loads and engine speeds of up to 3,250 rpm via the CAMTRONIC variable valve timing system. It uses a particulate filter as well.
This new engine will debut in the W222 S-Class facelift.
New M264 four-cylinder petrol engine

Most Malaysians will be buying 200 and 250 badged Mercedes-Benz cars, so this should be the most interesting bit to read about. Like the M256 six-pot, the new four-cylinder engine gets a 48V system. The turbochargers are now twin-scroll turbos, and there’s a particulate filter in the exhaust system.
However, instead of an ISG sandwiched in the gearbox, the M264 uses a belt-driven 48V starter-alternator (BSA) mounted where the conventional alternator usually sits. Mercedes-Benz says the BSA will allow improvements to the engine’s auto idle stop/start operation, electric boost at engine speeds of up to 2,500 rpm, energy recovery up to 12.5 kW and coasting with the engine turned off.

Hey broAs much as welcome new bros to Merc, you gotta ask what's the rationale for a GLA ?
If you need a people carrier, the BMW 216GT and styling. The GLA is like an A class that sits higher. 
It's stylish but not that roomy. 
For more room the B180 is actually bigger inside. Otherwise the KIA carens is a BMW lookalike for a lot less and drives pretty well. 
See how often you need six seats. If it's a must then the BMW will be a better bet. 
Otherwise the C class will possible sit five. 
If the mpv looks don't get you don't, the B200 is a nice car. 
Furthermore the FC of the B class or even the BMW is a lot better. 
You will get used to the stalk but again if that matters the BMW is more conventional. 
Ask yourself a hard question as to why the CLA - brand, style or a need?
If I had your budget and need to move more people I will consider the BMW 218GT or a second hand petrol version if diesel worries you. 
But do test drive the B200 and squeeze them during the coming motor show :)

It sounds like you are at where I was a while back.

I like the B180 because it's easy to drive, very safe and easy for my mum to get into. Enough power for me. Remember it drives in a more stately fashion so you don't feel or hear the roar. 
It's definitely faster than the lander but so are a lot of cars.

If you mainly move five pax or less, then you have to decide if you really need six or seven seats. That costs money.

For BMW and Merc your car will always be worth something because of their overtrade strategy. 
Watch for their promos.

Is overtrade still basically inflating your old car's "trade-in value" so you pay less downpayment, take a larger loan and therefore actually pay more in the long run?
 
Or is it really actually boosted trade in value resulting in lower cost?

Conti brands' overtrade is not targeted at marginal car buyers.
 
these buyers typically don't really need these tricks to get larger loan. On the contrary, most of these buyers are trying to take the minimum loan to enjoy the discounts and service credits tied to the deals.
 
Conti's seeming large overtrade amount is usually not as attractive when you hear them quote you below market rate for your car...the only exception is when your car is on brink of scrapping where they cannot quote you any lower...

these buyers typically don't really need these tricks to get larger loan. On the contrary, most of these buyers are trying to take the minimum loan to enjoy the discounts and service credits tied to the deals.
 
Conti's seeming large overtrade amount is usually not as attractive when you hear them quote you below market rate for your car...the only exception is when your car is on brink of scrapping where they cannot quote you any lower...
IMO overtrade together with their agent resale offer price are tools to allow them to have buffer to play around their final selling price to maintain their profit margin.This way they get a more predictable revenue on each car they sell.
The risks of fluctuations due to coe, exchange rate, etc, will then be passed onto the consumers.

Is overtrade still basically inflating your old car's "trade-in value" so you pay less downpayment, take a larger loan and therefore actually pay more in the long run?
 
Or is it really actually boosted trade in value resulting in lower cost?
Instead of giving you outfront discount, they give you higher overtrade so your old car cost "higher" value.  
Resulting:
 
1. You paying lower down payment.
2. AD still "maintain" their high selling price of their cars.

this probably also applies to other makes, their in-house isn't that good when they take over your existing car.. even if it is also a merc.
if u have the time to wait, sell it on your own.
the amount you get selling on yourself is likely higher than the amount from them + OT thrown in.
 
otherwise, wait till your car is near scrap when there is not much value left anyway.
so with OT, you'll reap more out of it.

Hi guys,

I just wana share the experience today that i had when at C&C.
Please do share yours as i wana compare the "Mercedes experience" that i had.

 
I was interested in the new C180/C200 coupe so I approach the counter, the staff was polite and nice. Soon a SE was "assign" to assist me.When approached by the SE, he ask which car im interested in so i told him its the C class coupe and would like to have a test drive.
So he immediately ask for my driver licence and walk away to prepare the car.
Although I did not ask, he did not brief or show me around the c class coupe, as im not familiar with the equipment or tech that is in it.
(example like: kick to open boot, auto parking feature, and the audio 20)

 
After 10mins he arrive with the car and we hop into it.Upon getting into the car, he did not explain to me the controls until i asked him to. Not everyone drives a mercedes right?
So I was briefed for less than a min like how to shift gears and the signal lights..... that's all.. and off I go.
The coupe sits really low and i love it. I test drove the C180 coupe and it feels punchy in the sports+ mode.
They don't have the C200 version for me to try it out (omg really C&C??). Requested for C200 sedan but was out for servicing.
The suspension is soft and good. Not sure about the sports suspension in AMG line as they only have ONE test drive car.

While inside the car i ask about the difference between the C180 vs C200.SE said: "Oh.. only the engine is bigger..."
i said: "All of that for 25k difference?"
SE said: "Yes"
i said: "i thought the leathery is different?"
SE said: "hmm... ah yes.. the leather is abit different..."
i said: "How about the dash and upper door trims? They look cheap for a almost $200k car, can i pay additional for it to be upholstered"
SE said: "Nope there isn't any."
i said: "Why not?"
SE said: "All models comes in as standard and we do not have this option."
i siad: "Even the C200 and C300?"
SE said: "Yes."
(We did talk more in details but these are the gist of it)

 
I was pretty sure i've read it before somewhere regarding C180 vs C200 and here are the difference:1. LED intelligent Light System.
2. Leather upholstery
3. Exhaust system with two visible tailpipe trim (not sure what it this... can some one verify?)

 
I've found out that someone had paid and gotten their car's dash & upper door panel upholstered. Its a new C class coupe too.http://www.sgmerc.com/topic/21318-2016-mercedes-c-class-coupe/

My conclusion is that the SE is pretty unprepared and unaware of their own products.
So the experience was pretty turned off. After the ride, we sit down, no drinks were offered.He eventually did not even quote me a price as he said because the COE recently release so he can't provide a proper quote.
He did not mention that will get back to me if it does.
What he actually does:
1. Tell me my current car trade in value. (its pretty low compared to its competitors, up to 7k)
2. Current 3k OT and 3K service.

He did not mention of any freebies or existing on running promotion where there actually is (early bird promotion for certain models).One of my sibling was there and actually interested in one of the promotional models but he held back and didn't mention until i spoke of the promotion title.

 
So i left the place without knowing much about the car, as he seems "busy" and really wish end this quickly.He did not provide any details regarding any good feature that will entice a customer to buy. Nowadays Mercedes cars sells their own right?
He told me buying this car now is almost like a "risk" as C&C will not lock any prices even you paid a down payment.
If COE went up, you paid the balance, there is no other way unless you forfeit the down payment.
Reason being their waiting time is 6 months.
(Vs other branded competitors does lock in and honour the price. If COE goes down, they will adjust the your price accordingly)

 
So to conclude, it was a bad experience for me for the first visit at C&C.Please share what you guys experience specially those who purchased the C205.
Thanks!

I know some conti brand list prices are permanently marked up. When you visit the showroom they'll tell you there's a "promo" and the actual price is around minus $10-20K than what it says on the price list. Does Merc do this?
 
How's Merc over-trade/trade-in as compared to Audi/BMW?

I know some conti brand list prices are permanently marked up. When you visit the showroom they'll tell you there's a "promo" and the actual price is around minus $10-20K than what it says on the price list. Does Merc do this?
 
How's Merc over-trade/trade-in as compared to Audi/BMW?

 
They got their own sales tactics. If things sells well, they wun offer tat much ... if they are eager to sell .. they offer more.
 
For your reference of how much my 6yr old jap car trade in.... merc late 20k.... bmw early 30k... audi mid 40k.
 
From my observation, Merc in general dun mark up as much or trade in as much. If you view their OMV, total base cost to import the car and the premium % they charge over it. Merc has the lowest vs bmw or audi.
Depending on which equivalent class you looking at....Merc general ard 20~40%... bmw / audi can be up to 30~50+% or more.

Mercedes has an overtrade thing which is variable. The amount varies according to their current promotion and what car they want to push.  E.g. A few months back, they were promoting their b class and gave 5k more overtrade for it versus the A class and CLA. Before that they were clearing their C class and the overtrade could be as high as 20k depending on your car. Of course you can sell it outside too. 
Do your sums. The current offer isn't too great IMO. Try waiting till they have the numbers they can offer for the motor show. 
That deal will only last for the four days of the show. But you can book at the showroom too

This way their list selling price remains quite constant but the deal price varies.  Right now their cat b cars may be more attractive due to the COE. If you are serious and need a rep you can pm me. Cheers

For Merc it depends on what cars/ models are are they receiving from the manufacturer. They will clear/ push for these models. If the model/ colors in not in this list then they will give little or no discount.

Ur experience is not unique to C&C
Its specific to individual SEs which can happen for any brand, so down to bad luck
 
For sale people, their job is to market to clinch the deal for their commission
Real problematic SEs wont be able to survive long in the industry
One way is to search for their top sales people or referred by friends
 
For C & C very easy to ask for change of SE, for argument's sake, u can go down every week and ask for a different SE if u are not happy with the service. In reality there are many SEs there who will very eager to get your business
 
In general, the young rookies will work very hard for you, follow up with you and appear more hungry etc
The older ones with a long list of old clients may appear more atas a bit  
 
Very sure you will have a much happier experience next time

Just wana share my re-visit to C&C.... 
I met up with a new SE yesterday. He/she was nice and immediately go through the specs and some details and cool thing about the car,trying to "sell" it , which I feel that should be the way... /thumbs up.He/she is keen and responsive, when I threw him questions that he was not sure, He/she is quick to verify. Plus point.Spend almost an hour to test drive both C180 coupe and C200 sedan (no coupe available). Good patience.He/she did quote me, explain in details plus all the package and freebies. All in all I've spend 2 1/2 hrs plus there, really different experience.
I was very tempted and felt his sincerity. His/her quote was aggressive even when i didn't push him/her....YET. Will definitely do so when i prepared my credit card/cheque I'm very happy with the service. Anyone wana his/her contacts can PM me.

The only thing that I wasn't quite happy about which wasn't from the SE but the company so call "factory policy".There are this issue of having different leather upholstery for the dash and door panel, released on different period, while paying the SAME price.C&C choose the easy way out by excluding it in future models. They blame it on the factory's policy.So now in the market carried by C&C have two different trims, one looks more higher end, the other missing out on the leather trims.I asked the SE and he/she said even I'm willingly paid for it, it still can't be done (on certain equipment line only.. its complicated T_T).Calm was told by his sales/product manager on the phone. Really feel left out and unjust.I feel as a big company like C&C, consistent quality is important. Having different trims level in the market is unfair to those who bought later.Even its an factory production issue, this can be ironed out. And by explaining the quality inconsistency, I strongly believe they will soften their tone. Even incurring the slightly heavier cost shouldn't be an issue right? Why make the customer confuse and frustrated?If its better I guess there are no complains, as people can argue that things will only get better. But getting worst and for the SAME price, its norm for people to get upset over it.Lets face it, we are made to think this way.Plus it might affect the resellability of the car. Suddenly those cars with better trims that sold previously are more sought after. 
Hopefully by my 3rd/4th visit im ready to sign the dotted line... Cheers.

Hope it works out. I told him to take care of you and you are a serious buyer hence there was no need to go back and forth. But this policy is a bit too rigid. However some dealers don't even have options so I guess having too many options or too little are both bad.

http://mercedesblog.com/new-9-speed-gearbox-the-more-the-better/
 

 
Mercedes will replace on medium term the 7-speed automatic gearbox on the models with rear wheel drive, with a 9-speed automatic transmission which will be available also for the four-cylinder engines.
With a few months ahead of Range Rover, Mercedes presented the first 9-speed automatic gearbox in the world meant for the premium segment. The new gearbox, named 9G-Tronic, will replace on medium term the current automatic gearbox 7G-Tronic. The new transmission came out with E 350 BlueTec and it is available now on four versions of CLS facelift (meaning CLS 220 BlueTec, CLS 250 Blue Tec, CLS 350 BlueTec and CLS 500). Subsequently it will also be mounted on other versions of E-Class, C, S, ML and the next GLK.
The new gearbox is already being produces at Stuttgart in Germany and it will be made at the Mercedes plant in Sebes, Romania, starting 2016, the production in Romania will have to supplement the demand as the new gearbox is introduced on other models.
What brings this new automatic gearbox and what are the benefits of the additional two gears? Nowadays, the automotive industry follows the motto “the more the better”.
The two extra gears offer a lower rev level at higher speeds: only 1350 rpm at 120 km/h and 2700 rpm at 250 km/h

The additional two gears provide a direct advantage at least from a certain point of view: the distance between the ratio between the first and the ninth gear is 9.15, which means that it is an important part regarding the efficiency. Thus, E 350 BlueTec can reach higher speeds at incredibly low revs. This translates for instance in driving at 120km/h while the rev counter shows only 1350 rpm and, furthermore, at E 350 BlueTec’s maximum speed of 250km/h is being reached an rev of only 2700 rpm. Through comparison, at the competitors like BMW and Audi, the distance between the ratio from the first and the 8th gear, respectively 7th gear is about 8 or 7, thus meaning that at maximum speed, the six-cylinders diesel engines from BMW and Audi are rotating at a higher revs with 500 or even 1000 rpm in the top gear of the transmission. Mercedes pledges for an official average fuel consumption extremely modest for E 350 BlueTech of only 5.3 l/100 km (138g/km CO2 emissions), with a minimum of 4.7 l/100 km for extra urban.
Not only the efficiency is the advantage of the large distance between the ratio  from the first and the ninth gear, but also the driving comfort. Theoretically, taking into consideration the huge torque of 620 Nm of the 3-liter diesel available from 1600rpm, the Mercedes engine would do honorable with only three or four gears, while the nine gears offer more refinement and driving comfort.
With a weight less than 100 kg, the new 9-speed gearbox is lighter than the actual 7-speed automatic gearbox

Despite the two additional gears and a maximum transferable torque of 1000 Nm, the new transmission does not take more space than the 7 gears one and, furthermore, it is lighter than the previous one, with a weight of less than 100 kg. The gear housing is composed of two components: the aluminum housing of the torque converter and the transmission housing made from magnesium alloy, while the sump is made of plastic. Even though there are two additional gears, the 9-speed transmission also has four semi-axle and six shift elements instead of five as found in the previous gearbox.
The main mechanical pump, considerably smaller than the previous one is located close to the main axle, it is chain driven and it is being operated by a auxiliary powered pump. Thus, the lubrication and the cooling are being actively controlled upon request, in order to adapt to the stop & start system. Due to the enhance of the hydraulic circuit from the torque converter, the transmission efficiency goes up till 92%, minimizing the loss in the transfer from the torque to the engine and to the transmission shaft.
Similar to the 7G-Tronic Plus, the gearbox provides the Economy, Sport and Manual modes and another Short-term M mode. This is enabled on the Eco and Sport modes only if the drivers engage a certain gear using the steering wheel-mounted paddle shifters and it remains active when manually changing the gears or if it maintains a sporty driving style. This is entirely different from the permanent Manual mode available in combination with the AMG Line package declutching it after a period of time.

New models and a new MFA II platform?
http://www.motorauthority.com/news/1104360_2018-mercedes-benz-a-class-spy-shots
 

 
A new generation of the Mercedes-Benz A-Class is brewing and we have new spy shots.
The prototypes reveal many of the details of the upcoming compact hatchback, the nameplate's fourth generation.
The proportions match those of the current model, which can be seen in some of the shots, but we can see the wheelbase is longer—evidenced by the stretched rear doors. This should result in some much-needed space in the cabin.
 

2018 Mercedes-Benz A-Class spy shots
 

Speaking of the cabin, though heavily disguised it appears Mercedes' designers are integrating the central screen with the dash instead of attaching it on as in the current model.
Another change is the positioning of the side mirrors. They are now mounted on the doors instead of higher up at the base of the A-pillars. This should result in improved visibility. And those strange markings at the top of the windshield are likely sensors for various driver aids.
The new A-Class is expected to be the first model to ride on the next-generation version of the current MFA (Modular Front-drive Architecture) platform used in compact cars from Mercedes and Infiniti. Referred to as MFA2, the next-generation platform will bring weight savings plus greater capacity for alternative drivetrains. A stretched version of this platform will underpin the next B-Class, CLA and even a new SUV rumored to be called the GLB.

But CnC is moving MB by the tens if not hundreds per month. While even the biggest PI might be just selling a handful per month. And each PI will be considered a separate account by MB. 
 
So a PI customised order might take 2.5 months to produce and 1 month to ship and 1 month to homologate. 
 
A CnC customised order might take 2 months just to queue for the factory production slot and the rest of the process will be similar to PI's. 
 
 
I suspect PIs don't deal directly with MB. Instead,  they might be using overseas dealers' account with MB to do the ordering.

I think there's a bit of confusion for new Merc buyers, so I will try to explain a little about their Overtrade policy, and I hope other seniors can chip in...
 
You will see a certain price on places like SGmart, ------ or even on thir brochures and websites.
 
Then you will be offered the ubiquitous "Overtrade":
 
Basically it's a discount. BUT the only way you get to enjoy it is if you have a car to trade in.
 
Essentially Republic Auto - their used car arm will take in your car. Now the amount may vary and it will depend on their current promotion and of course the state of your car.
 
Eg if they are offering a deal to push the A Class, they will give something like 10k or more to entice you.
This is on top of the buy in value. The buy in value is not as good for cars which aren't near scrap.
 
If you have a 9 plus year old car, that's the ideal. Then you give it to them upon collecting your car.
 
So the net discount for you can be
 
SRP 150 000
OT say 10k
Your scrap value of say 10k
 
So the NET price of the car is 140k minus the scrap value and the effective amount you pay is 130k. So that's why sometimes you see discrepancies on the amount people say they paid versus the SRP.
 
Merc isn't the only dealer who does this.
Lexus, BMW etc all  offer this, the OT amount may vary. And it's seasonal. Now for example the OT on the C Class, B Class etc isn't high, because they aren't pushing these cars.
 
So contact your rep (pm me if you do need one) and then compare.
 
Months before I closed my deal, the price on the car was almost 10k more, then they dropped the price for a promotion.
 
So put your ear to the ground and wait ... if you can..

But I don't quite understand the rationale, as I agree with earlier comment that the OT is meant to give the perception of a higher price and help the buyer get a larger loan.The overtrade mechanism (OT) is also designed to go some ways to clear the buyer's old car outstanding loan and the nett effect is to have $ left over (after paying off outstanding loan) to help reduce the down payment for new car. Meaning the buyer will fork out less cash as money down to book the new car, making it palatable for new car buyers. This is called incentivizing the sale. That is why OT needs trade in car to work. 
This is an effective tool for selling new cars - by topping up the value of old trade in car and subsidizing from the margin from the new car. However, one needs to be aware of market value of one's old car (can get quotes from car dealers) before negotiating with C&C as used car quotes from Republic Auto are kinda lower than market.

Is there a requirement to stay for the entire period of the loan?
 
I have friends who took loans for Subaru and BMW all paid off the loan with reduced interest after only 1 month, but you must give the bank 1 month notice that you are redeeming the loan.
 
SE will normally ask you to stay with the loan for at least 1 year, but I think the loan agreement with the bank does not have a minimum period or a heavy penalty for early redemption of loan.

Is there a requirement to stay for the entire period of the loan?
 
I have friends who took loans for Subaru and BMW all paid off the loan with reduced interest after only 1 month, but you must give the bank 1 month notice that you are redeeming the loan.
 
SE will normally ask you to stay with the loan for at least 1 year, but I think the loan agreement with the bank does not have a minimum period or a heavy penalty for early redemption of loan.

 
You can do prepayment and that is what the SE advices but the penalty is still there. The rebate level is calculated differently and usually there is a clawback of 20% rebate and a 1% penalty on balance.
 
Example, if you take a 6 year loan at 2.68% interest rate for 99k loan, the total interest paid is around 16k. The effective interest rate is a whopping 5%. If you prepay after 1 year, the total interest or extra you paid will be around 8k. Better than 16k but hardly insignificant. 
 
The savings is small because of the penalty which makes the case for prepayment a bit grey. The remaining 5year loan has an effective interest rate of 3.45% (calculated based on the savings) which is on the high side but lower than 5%.
 
I made a spreadsheet for the calculation. If you pay off everything in one month, the interest you will pay is $4.6k which is probably less than the freebies they are offering. That is why most people take the loan. I am not sure if mercedes allow prepayment after one month.

I am trying to calculate the penalty for a two loan scenario.
 
Loan A at 100k 6 years 2.68%
Loan B at 70k 3 years 2.68%
 
On first calculation, the Loan B saves $10k in interest paid. But one need to calculate the lost opportunity cost for putting in your money early in. I calculated that Loan A will give one an average of $29k more money over 6 years. If I used a return of 2.5% on those money (no compunding, too complicated maths) it will give 4.35k. To the delta is actually $5.6k, roughly.
 
The numbers get even murkier if you include the option to do prepayment. If Loan A prepay after one year, I think it narrows it down to around $3.5k

The OT is a bonus sum - a discount, so the best way to enjoy it is to bring them a car which is due for scrap.
It's not dependant on the car value.
That counts towards the value of your car, which is on top of this.
 
 
Basically there's a bit of VOODOO here, as the fudge factor allows them to keep the SRP high, and the final price is something between you and the agent.
 
Eg when my good friend booked the C180 in Feb last year, due to the low COE, his final price was almost as low as a B Class! He took an older C180, less specs, high OT and the low COE all factored in towards a low nett price. 
 
So the OT will be higher for the cars they want to push. Eg when I booked, if I wanted the Fungus Green color, I would have gotten 3k more discount.. but it was not to my taste... I suppose if I parked in a forest, I might not be able to find my car.. :)

See my earlier post bro..
 
The OT has Nothing to do with the scrap car value.
 
Say a car SRP = 180k
OT is what the agent gives as a discount. The condition is you must trade in a car. Any car ( only condition is that you own it > 6months apparently) 
 
Say OT = 10k
 
Then whatever value you get for your car is dependant on the SALE price of your current car. Eg if you have a 5 year old Camry and you get an offer of 50k for it.
 
So you pay 180-10 net, then minus the 50k for the Camry.
 
The net price is 170k, PLUS whatever freebies they give. That's the ad trick. They will add in the freebies which you get if you get a loan.
 
Eg Nano, DVR, service credits, solar film etc, things which I have posted earlier. Say all these have a net value of 10k, then they will say your car is 180-OT-Freebies or 160k.
 
So the ad will say, get a C180 for 160k.

I don't think I can make it any clearer!
 
Other bros, please chip in especially if I am mistaken.. cheers

I recall the rep telling me that that the 2017 models will mostly come with Airplay, so their prices are higher..

Current 2016 models or the ones being made in Hungary and will be on a boat to you, with Airplay.

AirPlay is listed as "new" in the feature list. Others is parking pilot, and another safety feature.

Any messing about / mods will technically mean that your car is liable to have the warranty voided. That comes from the rep.

I hope this helps others who will be collecting their rides:
 
Steps in buying and collecting your Merc
 

The car selection process :
 
That's listed here:
 
 
http://www.mycarforum.com/topic/2704141-your-car-buying-decision-process/?p=6027828
 
 
 
 
 
So you have set your eyes, heart and wallet on that three pointed star car.
 
Now I don't need to tell you that you should have done your due diligence on a few things:
 
- buy it because you like the car, the features, ride, safety etc etc. Not just for the badge. Well at least be clear why you put your hard earned cash on it!
- do your sums on the outlay, financing etc
- that includes the loan package, the duration, interest rate etc
- find a good rep who will serve you well, during the sale and more important, after you have coughed up the dough..
- look at the spec sheet, and make sure whatever you want is in black and white
- go through the details, eg, black leather, may come with black trim, and if you want a lighter trim check that 
- some things are not included, and you should go through the list that the rep gives you, and get them to sign off on it. If it's not on paper, it's not going to be there. There are no freebies

* Entry level Mercs don't get real leather, and the dash isn't covered with leather either, so do check your specs if you want the real deal.
 
Now for the buying part:
 
Some words about the overtrade:
http://www.mycarforum.com/topic/2703413-mercedes-owners-thread/?p=6021074
 
 
- check the NETT price, which is what you pay after deducting the overtrade, any further discounts, without including the service credits. Discounts can be offered on certain models, when they need to push for sales on these models, and come on top of the OT. 
- add on the scrap car value
 
That's what you need to pay.
 
 
Then confirm the loan package, interest rate, duration etc.
 
Confirm what's the freebie deal:
- welcome pack
A computer backpack, key chain holder, wallet
- Nano sealant X 2 - do this ASAP to seal in the freshness of the car
- interior cleaning X 1
- polish X 1
- windscreen cleaning X 2
- chemical wash of the aircon X 3
- tire repair X 6
- 12 car pick ups- Huber Optik Solar Film- JS 400 front and back camera- free compact umbrella
 
(your package may vary - eg if you get a higher end model, you may get more)
 
Service credits begin at $3000 and up. You can trade it in for cash.
 
 
Confirm color of the car, leather type, trim and additional specs - if you customise, the package price may not apply or you need to wait longer
 
Confirm delivery date: this can take months, so make sure you can swop out your existing car at the same time - you may even need to renew road tax
 
Once you sign, there's a draft contract that you get, and the actual form is sent to you in less than a month. One more contract will be sent nearer the delivery date if it's much later.
 
You pay the COE deposit of 10k, plus the deposit of 10%. You can use your credit card for this. 
 
You will also be asked to take up their insurance from AIG for getting the freebies. You can also use your Credit Card for this.
 
In a few days time, you will get notice of the loan approval. The loan and insurance start when you get your car registered. 
 
Then the wait begins. 
 
In the mean time, you can download the Mercedes Benz guides and MyMB - the app for the manual and the service booking app. 
 
There are many functions, so do read up.
 
COE bidding:
 
Merc usually gives a 6 bid non guaranteed deal, but they will get it for you! The rebate may not be great, but you will get your car.Collection:
 
Now after that seemingly never ending wait, you get your car   Your rep will call you up, tell you when he will collect that cheque, which happens two to three weeks ahead.You register a few days ahead of the collection, then they install the camera (from Eurostyle JS 400, no park mode) and solar film etc. He will ask you if you want the back window to be darker. The insurance starts once you register, and you can pay for it with your credit card.A few days later, you will then make your way to C&C for the collection. 

For budget level cars like the A and B class, you probably have to take delivery at 209 Pandan Gardens. Drive in, park your old car at level two, there will be reserved lots for you. Clear out your old car and head into the special lounge to meet your rep.For higher end cars, they will do the collection at Alex or Ubi etc, and if you ask, they may get things like the Nano Protection done first. For the more basic models, you need to do it separately and do ask your rep if he can allow you to do it right after the collection, so you seal in the fresh paintwork.In the lounge, he will run through the paperwork first,  insurance, finance etc.Then you will proceed to the car. 
 
So on the day, you can make sure of some checklists like this: 
http://www.mycarforum.com/topic/1802820-new-car-checklist/
 
 
 
But the rep will also give you a list to go through. Do take a half day off, it's a good idea to bring a torchlight and go through, looking for scratches and dents. The rep will take you through the functions etc.
 
 
You hand over the keys of your old car, get a LTA pin to handover ownership and pass him your old insurance form to sort out. Spend a day taking out the old stuff, don't forget any items under the carpets etc
 
Other items to consider:
 
 
There's no 1000km run in, the rep says, so go ahead and enjoy that ride   Try the various controls, and switches, but main thing is check the paintwork. And take some pics  
 

 


			
				


	Edited January 18, 2017 by therock

I hope this helps others who will be collecting their rides:
	Steps in buying and collecting your Merc
 


 
The car selection process :
 
That's listed here:
http://peteswrite.blogspot.sg/2017/01/my-car-buying-process.html
 
 
 
 
 
So you have set your eyes, heart and wallet on that three pointed star car.
 
Now I don't need to tell you that you should have done your due diligence on a few things:
 
- buy it because you like the car, the features, ride, safety etc etc. Not just for the badge. Well at least be clear why you put your hard earned cash on it!
- do your sums on the outlay, financing etc
- that includes the loan package, the duration, interest rate etc
- find a good rep who will serve you well, during the sale and more important, after you have coughed up the dough..
- look at the spec sheet, and make sure whatever you want is in black and white
- go through the details, eg, black leather, may come with black trim, and if you want a lighter trim check that 
- some things are not included, and you should go through the list that the rep gives you, and get them to sign off on it. If it's not on paper, it's not going to be there. There are no freebies
 
* Entry level Mercs don't get real leather, and the dash isn't covered with leather either, so do check your specs if you want the real deal.
 
Now for the buying part:
 
Some words about the overtrade:
http://peteswrite.blogspot.sg/2017/01/overtrade-how-does-it-work.html
 
 
- check the NETT price, which is what you pay after deducting the overtrade, any further discounts, without including the service credits. Discounts can be offered on certain models, when they need to push for sales on these models, and come on top of the OT. 
- add on the scrap car value
 
That's what you need to pay.
 
 
Then confirm the loan package, interest rate, duration etc.
 
Confirm what's the freebie deal:
- welcome pack
A computer backpack, key chain holder, wallet
- Nano sealant X 2 - do this ASAP to seal in the freshness of the car
- interior cleaning X 1
- polish X 1
- windscreen cleaning X 2
- chemical wash of the aircon X 3
- tire repair X 6
- 12 car pick ups
- Huber Optik Solar Film
- JS 400 front and back camera
- free compact umbrella
 
(your package may vary - eg if you get a higher end model, you may get more)
 
Service credits begin at $3000 and up. You can trade it in for cash.
 
 
Confirm color of the car, leather type, trim and additional specs - if you customise, the package price may not apply or you need to wait longer
 
Confirm delivery date: this can take months, so make sure you can swop out your existing car at the same time - you may even need to renew road tax
 
Once you sign, there's a draft contract that you get, and the actual form is sent to you in less than a month. One more contract will be sent nearer the delivery date if it's much later.
 
You pay the COE deposit of 10k, plus the deposit of 10%. You can use your credit card for this. 
 
You will also be asked to take up their insurance from AIG for getting the freebies. You can also use your Credit Card for this.
 
In a few days time, you will get notice of the loan approval. The loan and insurance start when you get your car registered. 
 
Then the wait begins. 
 
In the mean time, you can download the Mercedes Benz guides and MyMB - the app for the manual and the service booking app. 
 
There are many functions, so do read up.
 
COE bidding:
 
Merc usually gives a 6 bid non guaranteed deal, but they will get it for you! The rebate may not be great, but you will get your car.
 
Collection:
 
Now after that seemingly never ending wait, you get your car  
 
Your rep will call you up, tell you when he will collect that cheque, which happens two to three weeks ahead.
 
You register a few days ahead of the collection, then they install the camera (from Eurostyle JS 400, no park mode) and solar film etc. He will ask you if you want the back window to be darker. The insurance starts once you register, and you can pay for it with your credit card.
 
A few days later, you will then make your way to C&C for the collection. 
 
For budget level cars like the A and B class, you probably have to take delivery at 209 Pandan Gardens. Drive in, park your old car at level two, there will be reserved lots for you. Clear out your old car and head into the special lounge to meet your rep.
 
For higher end cars, they will do the collection at Alex or Ubi etc, and if you ask, they may get things like the Nano Protection done first. For the more basic models, you need to do it separately and do ask your rep if he can allow you to do it right after the collection, so you seal in the fresh paintwork.
 
In the lounge, he will run through the paperwork first,  insurance, finance etc.
 
Then you will proceed to the car. 
 
So on the day, you can make sure of some checklists like this: 
http://peteswrite.blogspot.sg/2016/08/checklist-when-buying-car.html
 
 
 
But the rep will also give you a list to go through. Do take a half day off, it's a good idea to bring a torchlight and go through, looking for scratches and dents. The rep will take you through the functions etc.
 
 
You hand over the keys of your old car, get a LTA pin to handover ownership and pass him your old insurance form to sort out. Spend a day taking out the old stuff, don't forget any items under the carpets etc
 
Other items to consider:
 
 
There's no 1000km run in, the rep says, so go ahead and enjoy that ride  
 
Try the various controls, and switches, but main thing is check the paintwork. And take some pics  

Good write-up but it neglected to mention that for a very few models, you get a delivery party and champagne. Adding for completeness.

Found some interesting info on using the paddle shifts:
 

My car has paddle shifters and seven gears. I have the habit of skipping through the gears rapidly, like from sixth to third.
When I was driving a manual car, I used to shift directly from fourth to second gear. There was no damage to my manual car's gearbox then. But if I do it with my current car's paddle shifters, will I damage or wear out the transmission prematurely?
Unlike manual transmissions, it is not possible to shift directly from sixth to third in an automatic car.
You need to run down the sequence, through fifth and fourth, before arriving at third.
In a manual box, the driver did all the clutch work.
 
 
In an automated manual gearbox such as a double-clutch transmission, the computer makes all the decisions and commands the actuator to do the "clutch" work.
As the system is computer- controlled, there is no danger of shifting to a lower gear if the speed is too high for the ratio.
No matter how many times you flick the paddle, it will never switch from sixth to first, for example, at a speed of 80kmh.
It works for upshifts too. The transmission will not allow you to select a high gear if the speed is too low.
So there is no risk of damaging your vehicle's transmission if you paddle down (or up) rapidly.

In my view, the value of an in-car camera is not monetary. If you get into an accident that doesn't involve any injuries, regardless of whose fault it is, ultimately, money will resolve the matter. Even if it's not your fault, but you have no evidence and end up having a claim made against your insurance, it's fine.
 
The value of an in-car camera is when you injure someone and face prosecution. That's when money can no longer solve the problem. Imagine hitting a reckless jaywalker or a cyclist or someone riding a scooter through no fault of yours and being charged by the police, without any evidence to defend yourself. That's when an in-car camera will pay its price many times over.

Although I don't agree with Merc, I can understand their anxiety over DVRs and other items which drain their battery.
If you read other car threads, there are quite a few owners complaining about the short lifespan of their batteries.
At the same time, you see lots of owners asking for all kinds of gadgets in their cars:
See the number of owners asking auto fold mirrors, keyless entry etc. All these functions will drain the battery. 
Add on parked mode, and you will see a long line of irate owners trying to claim warranty on their batteries.
 
Personally, I have switched to I drive mode, disabled the auto start stop. I also try to avoid using the radio / charging my phone etc when the car engine is turned off. 
 
I also shortened the duration of the "Go Home" and interior ambient lights, in an effort to save wear on the battery.
However, I will definitely want a DVR. In this day and age of drivers doing strange stunts, this is a vital way to protect ourselves.
In fact some insurance companies will reduce their premiums if you have a DVR.

I didn't read all the complicated back-and-forth, but it's really quite simple:
 
A DVR is worth having. Pretty much *every* car I see has at least a front facing one judging by the blinking LEDs.
 
Merc only offers the JS400, without park mode. It's not a great camera. The audio recording is crap - mine has crackles. The video is so-so, and you have to be up close to ID the plate. You need that special software (LogOn player) and special codecs to be able to view videos which means you'll need a PC. And finally there's no Wifi link, which means you'll have to remove the micro SD card to download your recordings. Easier said than done with the space constraints of my car. 
 
So if I had a choice, I would've gone with Blackvue, the setup I have in my BMW. But I don't, and the reason is that Merc will definitely void the warranty on the battery and possibly also the warranty on the electrical system if I were to get such a system installed. 
 
So I'm waiting out the 3 years and seeing how I feel about it. I don't really miss Park mode as I don't often park this car in unfamiliar places but I would much prefer another DVR.

W204 is not using TPMS only in W205 TPMS included.
W204 is getting what it called run flat monitoring, it measure rotation timing of each wheels. If there is one tyre rotation out of timing it will display "check tyre pressure". Lower pressure on tyre affect the diameter therefore also affect rotation timing. After preussure confirmed on all 4 tyres then need to reset the system.

What i see the tyre change shop guys do for tight fitted rims after they removed the nuts. They lower the car down from the jack to allow the weight of the car to press down on the contact patch to loosen the connection and then raise the jack again slightly. While holding the top half of the rim pulling it towards yourself,  use ur foot to kick at the bottom tyre portion inwards. 
 
Used these methods on my own with 100% result so far.

After driving for two days on my CLA180 SB, here is my impressions,
 
The mobile pairing is seamless. After I paired once, all my calls get routed to the car and I can access music via bluetooth without taking out my HP ever. The car just seems to know my HP is in the car. This makes the apple carplay kind of useless as I have to physically connect my iphone to the USB port. Do any of you use apple carplay regularly? If I need GPS, I almost always find it easier to use it on the phone itself, due to the touch screen UI. The apply car play UI hard to use due to lack of touch screen, unless I use SIRI which i am not familiar with. I asked my SE if CnC has an iphone dock, she says don't have. Is that true? Kind of weird to give apple carplay and don't have a dock....
 
My Aircon has to be set to 23.5 deg to feel cold. If it is set to 24 deg, it is just cool. Seems to be a regular issue with CLA180, not a big deal.
 
Eco start stop. This is probably discussed many times. I tried running with ECO start stop but it seems to be pretty useless. It will switch off the engine, but with the aircon set at 23.5deg, music on, it turns on maybe after 1 min, even before the light turns green sometimes. With the outside temperature being so warm in Singapore, the aircon has to work hard almost all the time, so eco start stop seems to be limited by the battery? Has anyone use this regularly? Does it increase the wear and tear on the Engine/Battery?
 
I am thinking if CnC can set the default to disable for Eco start stop. 
 
I did not know my car comes with active park assist, ie the car can park itself turning the steering wheel, all you need is to press the throttle. Tried it once, almost hit the low kerb on the side.... don't dare to try again.

bro dont be fool by those marketing gimmick. all these protection is only minimizing not 100% protection. leaving the stain or poo over night still bit into the coating. that is why they state you have to return to them for maintenance during their warranty period. in order for the coating to be effective all stain or poo must be wiped away within 24hrs from it deposition. to get the best out of these coating is to rinse the car daily to remove all the dirt and contamination.
 
you can do an experience yourself. dont wash your car let the dirt stay.. then after light rain.. you can see the rain drop on your car drying leaving water mark because the rain drop gather all the dust together and generally they are acidic. the light rain drop will not flow down because the dust on your car prevent it from flowing down. in science this is called the surface tension. they will bit into your coating if you do not remove them. of cos with coating it slows down the biting compared to one without but it will still bit. thus to get the best out of such coating is rinse your car regularly with water.
 
so dont be fool by those claim. there is also a saying.. 9H hardness will not scratch.. all bulls**t. ask them the 9H testing how they test.. the coating on your car is only in micron. with sufficient force the coating will still scratch (i do agree it will protect against fine scratch). so take note of what they claim to be scratch proof..

bro dont be fool by those marketing gimmick. all these protection is only minimizing not 100% protection. leaving the stain or poo over night still bit into the coating. that is why they state you have to return to them for maintenance during their warranty period. in order for the coating to be effective all stain or poo must be wiped away within 24hrs from it deposition. to get the best out of these coating is to rinse the car daily to remove all the dirt and contamination.
 
you can do an experience yourself. dont wash your car let the dirt stay.. then after light rain.. you can see the rain drop on your car drying leaving water mark because the rain drop gather all the dust together and generally they are acidic. the light rain drop will not flow down because the dust on your car prevent it from flowing down. in science this is called the surface tension. they will bit into your coating if you do not remove them. of cos with coating it slows down the biting compared to one without but it will still bit. thus to get the best out of such coating is rinse your car regularly with water.
 
so dont be fool by those claim. there is also a saying.. 9H hardness will not scratch.. all bulls**t. ask them the 9H testing how they test.. the coating on your car is only in micron. with sufficient force the coating will still scratch (i do agree it will protect against fine scratch). so take note of what they claim to be scratch proof..

http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/motoring/torque-shop-81
 

 
I did my first drive to Malaysia in my fairly new car recently and I had a flat tyre. Fortunately, I was able to pull in to a rest stop. But I was surprised to discover that there was no spare tyre. Instead there was something called a tyre repair kit. I was at a loss because I had no idea how to use the kit. Is this normal and unique to my car?
First and foremost, when you embark on a long-distance drive, you must give your vehicle a thorough check, including all the tyres (the spare too).
These days, many cars do not come with a spare tyre. To reduce weight and for convenience, a tyre repair kit is now a common flat-tyre fix, so you must know how to use it.
The repair kit comes with a puncture sealant and a tyre pump. What you need to do in the event of a puncture is clearly described in the owner's manual and, in most cases, on the repair kit itself.
The operation is fairly simple. First, you inject the pressurised can of sealant into the punctured tyre. You may then need to move the car a little to rotate the tyre so that the sealant is distributed evenly.
 
 
Wait a few minutes for the puncture to be sealed. Instructions on the can will state how many minutes. Then, plug in the compressor to the cigarette lighter socket, connect the pressure tube of the pump to the tyre valve and start the compressor. The pump has a gauge so you will know when the pressure is right.
The repair is not meant to be permanent. You should have the damaged tyre changed at the next town.

Reposting some useful info for bros who are collecting their new rides:
 
 
 

Got this off another forum:
 
Car essential package basically contain the followings
1) tyre patching x6
2) windscreen polishingx 3
3) aircon svc package
4) star interior ( I suppose is interior cleaning)
5)nano sealants x2
6)welcome pack ( dunno what it contains)
Total value : $3062
 
not too sure about the "Plus" difference.
 
you can also ask your SE and update us here.

 
 
Freebies that you can expect from Merc:
 
 
1. 3k service credit. anything more depend your bargain and model. E and above will be like 5k. A, B and C i think only 3k but can ask for more. i did it for my other car. usually within 500$more
2.. JS front back camera sure give
3. insurance some loyalty discount for next two year renewal.
4. 3D matt
5. solar film
6. some car essential package inclusive nano coat.
7. welcome pack.. laptop bag.
8. some amount of overtrade 
9. 12 or more pick ups for servicing
 
 

where to find accessories:
 
For a brick and mortar shop options:
 
Autobacs:
- the biggest selection, you can touch, ask questions etc
 
NTUC:
surprisingly good
 
SGgarage, and a few others. Mod shops that also sell some kit that you can add on. 
 
For serious electrical mods;
 
Elebest:
 
Max does all kinds of stuff: GPS, keyless, etc
 
ONLINE:
 
Ah this is where the interesting stuff begins:
 
Amazon:
Amazing place where you can get stuff that suits all kinds of cars. And don't limit yourself to Amazon USA. For the Merc, which is German in origin, try search in Amazon UK and De. They may be cheaper, and offer more options. Things like car mats, wipers, replacement parts, and more.
 
Ebay:
A traditional source, and I might get my window visors from there. Made in USA and sells for the same price as the ones from ebay Malaysia.
 
Aliexpress:
A huge market place, and like Taobao, it offers many items, which are not just made in China. I got a console shelf that fits in the console box between the seats, plus some red control knobs. Do compare prices, and see if it's cheaper than Amazon and vice versa.
 
Taobao:
Another large market, but it's in Chinese and I am not too familiar. There are options to ship over, so one can consider that too.  
 

Buying and collecting
 
- check the NETT price, which is what you pay after deducting the overtrade, any further discounts, without including the service credits. Discounts can be offered on certain models, when they need to push for sales on these models, and come on top of the OT. 
- add on the scrap car value
 
That's what you need to pay.
 
 
Then confirm the loan package, interest rate, duration etc.
 
Confirm what's the freebie deal:
- welcome pack
A computer backpack, key chain holder, wallet
- Nano sealant X 2 - do this ASAP to seal in the freshness of the car
- interior cleaning X 1
- polish X 1
- windscreen cleaning X 2
- chemical wash of the aircon X 3
- tire repair X 6
- 12 car pick ups- Huber Optik Solar Film- JS 400 front and back camera- free compact umbrella
 
(your package may vary - eg if you get a higher end model, you may get more)
 
Service credits begin at $3000 and up. You can trade it in for cash.
 
 
Confirm color of the car, leather type, trim and additional specs - if you customise, the package price may not apply or you need to wait longer
 
Confirm delivery date: this can take months, so make sure you can swop out your existing car at the same time - you may even need to renew road tax
 
Once you sign, there's a draft contract that you get, and the actual form is sent to you in less than a month. One more contract will be sent nearer the delivery date if it's much later.
 
You pay the COE deposit of 10k, plus the deposit of 10%. You can use your credit card for this. 
 
You will also be asked to take up their insurance from AIG for getting the freebies. You can also use your Credit Card for this.
 
In a few days time, you will get notice of the loan approval. The loan and insurance start when you get your car registered. 
 
Then the wait begins. 
 
In the mean time, you can download the Mercedes Benz guides and MyMB - the app for the manual and the service booking app. 
 
There are many functions, so do read up.
 
COE bidding:
 
Merc usually gives a 6 bid non guaranteed deal, but they will get it for you! The rebate may not be great, but you will get your car.Collection:
 
Now after that seemingly never ending wait, you get your car    Your rep will call you up, tell you when he will collect that cheque, which happens two to three weeks ahead.You register a few days ahead of the collection, then they install the camera (from Eurostyle JS 400, no park mode) and solar film etc. He will ask you if you want the back window to be darker. The insurance starts once you register, and you can pay for it with your credit card.A few days later, you will then make your way to C&C for the collection. 

For budget level cars like the A and B class, you probably have to take delivery at 209 Pandan Gardens. Drive in, park your old car at level two, there will be reserved lots for you. Clear out your old car and head into the special lounge to meet your rep.For higher end cars, they will do the collection at Alex or Ubi etc, and if you ask, they may get things like the Nano Protection done first. For the more basic models, you need to do it separately and do ask your rep if he can allow you to do it right after the collection, so you seal in the fresh paintwork.In the lounge, he will run through the paperwork first,  insurance, finance etc.Then you will proceed to the car. 
 
So on the day, you can make sure of some checklists like this: 
http://www.mycarforu...-car-checklist/
 
 
 
But the rep will also give you a list to go through. Do take a half day off, it's a good idea to bring a torchlight and go through, looking for scratches and dents. The rep will take you through the functions etc.
 
 
You hand over the keys of your old car, get a LTA pin to handover ownership and pass him your old insurance form to sort out. Spend a day taking out the old stuff, don't forget any items under the carpets etc

If it says "and above", you should go higher. Look to see if there is a "recommended RON".  
Most modern ECUs can run on RON that's lower than recommended. Boost is reduced, timing is retarded of course. Power output won't be nominal. I would trust your first impression butt dyno but not subsequent ones as we get habituated too quickly to extra power.
 
So if you have a forced induction performance car, you really should go for the highest pump RON you can get.
 
And if yours is a bread n butter car, does it matter? Save money!

Would like to ask the opinion of the more experienced guys here. Given the similar price point, would you guys get the new C43 AMG or the base model Cayman?
 
Is the price point similar? I thought the C43 was a tad more ex - about 10k+?
 
Anyway, I have not driven the Cayman. But I have driven the C43.
 
Wasn't too impressed. The car simply doesn't feel urgent enough. Let me wanting a lot more.
 
Between those two, I would seriously look at the Porsche - but again, I need to drive the Cayman to be sure. While I have lots of experience with DCTs in general, I have to confess I have limited experience with the PDK. I have tested a RUF 3800S with a DCT, but I'm not sure if it's equivalent to the PDK you get in a Porsche badged car. Still, a DCT transmission of any sort is still preferable to an auto (the C43 has a nine-speed auto).
 
Honestly, the C43 is considered an AMG-lite, not a fully-fledged AMG as such. The engine itself is not made at Affalterbach. In that sense, it is similar to my BMW M140i (the "M performance" line, informally considered "M-lite"). And now I'm going to make a pitch for my car or the close cousin, the M240i. Even though they're down on raw power compared to the C43, they also weigh less so the power:weight is actually higher on the Bimmers. Try driving one of these - they're quicker than an M2 in a straight line at legal speeds (and a bit above). Even though the transmission is also a torque converter auto, it's the practically bulletproof ZF 8-speed, which I love. Seriously, if you're thinking of the C43, get one of these and save yourself nearly 100k and put a bigger smile on your face.
Thank you guys for your comments. A lot of food for thought. I have yet to try the M2, will definitely add it to the list.

Quite out of topic for a Mercedes thread
 
But I have been buying cars for a long time, and the honest truth is the sales execs don't really give two cents how you dress or how you look
 
they know that dressing is no indicator of whether you have money to buy
 
More importantly to them, is whether you are a serious buyer or not
 
Can afford to buy - does not equal serious to buy
 
what this means is you could have $1 million dollar cash in your bank, but if you are not seriously looking to buy, they can feel it - and will not treat you as a serious buyer
 
to them there is an opportunity cost to attending to someone who is just looking around vs someone who is ready to buy
the one who is ready buy gives out different signals and asks different questions
 
for those who don't know, the SE at the showroom goes by queue system. this means they take the walk in customer by turn
 
so if their turn comes, and you just look look see see and they feel it, they will feel peeved because they wasted their turn. And some days they might only have 1 turn that day
 
if we understand that this is their livelihood , then we can empathize why they dont serve you whole heartedly if you not buying. Not great for the customer but understandable
 
so this how you dress issue is in your head 
 
* titbit: the place you seriously will feel sales staff see you no up is in designer boutiques when there are PRC China buyers - and there is you. It won't be because of your dressing but it is because the SE knows China buyers are going to buy 5 handbags, and you going to check price, haha. So again they will pick the customer who is going to make them more commissions

For eg. 
 
1)
CnC spec for GLC includes the intelligent Lighting system while most PI GLC try to pass off the run of the mill LED headlights as the same. This information can only be verified by going down to the showroom.
 
Worldwide, the GLC comes with halogen, HID, LED (passive LED) and Intelligent Lighting System (ie. active LED).
 
2) in other parts of the world, AMG line comes with normal round steering wheels but with alcantara seats. CnC AMG line comes with flat bottom sports steering wheel but the seats remain artico.
 
These are some of the answers only a competent CnC SE can provide. I was unable to get Mr Google to shed any lights.
 
I do not need the SE to have all the information at the finger tips but she/he must show that she/he is not quick to bulls*t and is willing to go find out the correct information soonest. That is professionalism I value in a good SE.

Artico means non leather? I noob.
Alcantara, to me is good for areas like roof lining but i prefer gen natural leather for seats ....

ILS = LED light that swivels to light up the part of the curve or corner as you turn your steering. 
 
I generally don't drive naked...so the parts of my body in direct contact with the seats I cannot really appreciate the subtle nuances. So artificial leather with high wear resistance and Low maintenance will suffice for me.
 
Alcantara serves to increase the friction for areas of the steering wheel and sides of the seats to offer more grip during spirited driving.
 
But if genuine leather rocks your boat, these are optional extras. Just a couple of Ks.
 
I rather spend the extra on things that matter to me more, eg. Panoroof, sports suspension.
 
That's the beauty of conti, you can option up your car to your satisfaction.

How long have you had your C Class? The Artico, how's the wear rate?

Artico is nice.
Not soft and stretchy like cowhide, but it feels durable and more stain resistant. But I wonder if I should clean or treat it with the same leather conditioners..

I am blessed to be unable to feel the difference through my pants/berms. Especially in air conditioned comfort of the car.
 
My wife's Saab has fake leather (2009 tech) and my GS (2009) has factory genuine leather with ventilation and heating.
 
To be absolutely honest, I feel no difference in the subtleness or "heat-retention" through the seat of my pants or finger touch.
 
Drove the Saab up to KL and back 2 to 3 times as the sole driver and drive my GS daily cross island.
 
On the other hand, the Saab's light beige fake leather holds up to abuse (Wife sequins, jeans metal parts, nails, kid's kicking of back of seat) much better than my GS factory black genuine leather which is already looking quite worn at the driver and front passenger seat. I dare say I take better care of my car than my Wife.
 
To be sure, if I am given a no extra cost choice between Artico vs Genuine leather, I will choose genuine leather simply for the extra selling factor when selling the car next time. I am a realist and the general perception is still genuine over fake. I will just have to spend more effort (regular cleaning and moisturising) then. But if they want extra money for it (Low few Ks), I have better ideas how to spend that money.
 
Once again, I am lucky I cannot feel the difference. Just like someone can live with attrage as a daily driver since they don't feel the need to spend more on a car.

To be sure, if I am given a no extra cost choice between Artico vs Genuine leather, I will choose genuine leather simply for the extra selling factor when selling the car next time. I am a realist and the general perception is still genuine over fake. I will just have to spend more effort (regular cleaning and moisturising) then. But if they want extra money for it (Low few Ks), I have better ideas how to spend that money.
 
Once again, I am lucky I cannot feel the difference. Just like someone can live with attrage as a daily driver since they don't feel the need to spend more on a car.
