I felt M2 engine note is better. M240i engine acceleration is better. But, what impressed me was Gay S. Signed today. Bye Bye F10 @RadX

Is the price point similar? I thought the C43 was a tad more ex - about 10k+?
 
Anyway, I have not driven the Cayman. But I have driven the C43.
 
Wasn't too impressed. The car simply doesn't feel urgent enough. Let me wanting a lot more.
 
Between those two, I would seriously look at the Porsche - but again, I need to drive the Cayman to be sure. While I have lots of experience with DCTs in general, I have to confess I have limited experience with the PDK. I have tested a RUF 3800S with a DCT, but I'm not sure if it's equivalent to the PDK you get in a Porsche badged car. Still, a DCT transmission of any sort is still preferable to an auto (the C43 has a nine-speed auto).
 
Honestly, the C43 is considered an AMG-lite, not a fully-fledged AMG as such. The engine itself is not made at Affalterbach. In that sense, it is similar to my BMW M140i (the "M performance" line, informally considered "M-lite"). And now I'm going to make a pitch for my car or the close cousin, the M240i. Even though they're down on raw power compared to the C43, they also weigh less so the power:weight is actually higher on the Bimmers. Try driving one of these - they're quicker than an M2 in a straight line at legal speeds (and a bit above). Even though the transmission is also a torque converter auto, it's the practically bulletproof ZF 8-speed, which I love. Seriously, if you're thinking of the C43, get one of these and save yourself nearly 100k and put a bigger smile on your face.

Hi,just got my cla180 on 28/04/2017.
Mine is the coupe version.
The coupe is quieter than the sb in my opinion.
I test drove the sb and the road noise seems louder.
Bear in mind that the Omv of the sb is around $3k more.
Ride is not harsh.in fact my missus commented that the ride is good.
That is coming from a bmw 7 series previously.
Cheers!

The CLA has a rimless door, so it relies heavily on a good rubber seal to retain the soundproofing.
It won't be as good as the best from Lexus, but all my friends with the CLA have no complaints.
But given it's reliance on such seals - two seals and the window glass goes up further when you close the door - you need to consider the deterioration of this soundproofing with the years.
 
Plus the QC on the lower models, YMMV. There was a lady who came into the forum to complain about the wind noise on her new CLA at 130 kph a few pages back. So it's subject to the owner's sensitivity on how bothered you are by the noise, cheers.

You get assigned a service rep, he's the one with the nice tie and sits in the showroom or service centre. He then calls a chap in blue to come in, who listens for such sounds, and then takes note of what needs to be.

Hi all CLA owners,
Good day.
 
I've a Q to ask of you guys. In the center of the front windscreen, I've seen that there is an open view area below the rear view mirror area. I'm wondering if this is the factory fitted camera for this car model? My ride was fitted with an front camera which is below the rear view mirror.
2nd Q was that every day, I need to manually change the drive mode to Individual as I hate the econ mode where it turns off the engine when waiting for the green traffic lights. Any idea how to make it stay in Individual mode?
BTW, I had asked the Sales Rep and they don't know.
 
Thanks 

 
I think the drive mode defaults to Comfort in all Mercedes cars. Same with my GT. I need to manually switch it to Individual when I want to. This happens after the ignition has been switched off for a few hours (never looked at the exact time cut off, though). If the ignition is turned on a short while after turning off, the last mode is "remembered".
 
The way it goes is this: Ignition switched off. Turned back on within a certain time (T1): car retains last used mode, and start up revs remain low VS turned back on within a slightly longer time (T2): car retains mode, but start up revs are high (cold start mode) VS turned back on after an even longer time (T3): full cold start behaviour: start up revs are high and default Comfort mode engaged.
 
A recode can probably get the car to behave the way you want. But a recode will almost certainly also void your warranty. It is also possible you will lose your coding with the next service (when they reset the computer or whatever).

I think the drive mode defaults to Comfort in all Mercedes cars. Same with my GT. I need to manually switch it to Individual when I want to. This happens after the ignition has been switched off for a few hours (never looked at the exact time cut off, though). If the ignition is turned on a short while after turning off, the last mode is "remembered".
 
The way it goes is this: Ignition switched off. Turned back on within a certain time (T1): car retains last used mode, and start up revs remain low VS turned back on within a slightly longer time (T2): car retains mode, but start up revs are high (cold start mode) VS turned back on after an even longer time (T3): full cold start behaviour: start up revs are high and default Comfort mode engaged.
 
A recode can probably get the car to behave the way you want. But a recode will almost certainly also void your warranty. It is also possible you will lose your coding with the next service (when they reset the computer or whatever).

For MB owners with keyless entry and start, how do you wash your own car? 
 
I find that the touch sensitive door handles great for daily use as it is very responsive and fast when locking and unlocking the car. Just that with the keyfob in my pocket and washing the car, just water jet from the hose or water splashing onto the handles will trigger the lock and unlock function. Not great when the mirrors keep folding and unfolding with the single honk of the locked status keeps sounding. 
 
Initially thought of leaving my key further away on the floor but not really a very elegant solution.
 
Then it occured to me (which I read somewhere) that if the key detected in the cabin, the default safety protocol is that any locking attempt on the door handle is invalidated. So theoretically, I can just leave the car keyfob in the car, close the door and start washing.  Anyone does this on a regular basis? Is it foolproof?

Just found out something, thought I share it here for fellow owners. 
 
If your car comes with TPMS, did you notice the cheapo looking grey plastic tire valve caps? So unbecoming of a premium conti brand to penny pinch and gave you cheap plastic valve covers, while other brands are running around with shiny metal caps? 
It's pretty cheap and at most a couple of dollars to change to metal ones but DON'T!! 
 
MB have very good reason to be "cheapo". The TPMS air valve are made from special metallic alloy and the commonly available metal air valve caps will corrode the contact surface rapidly, leading to the caps being fused to the valve threads. Once that happens, the only way to open the valve is to bring to tireshop where they will need to replace that valve. And TPMS valves comes in 1 whole unit with the sensors attached (at least for MB version) 
 
So, save that few dollars and leave the plastic ones on and potentially save yourself a few hundreds. 
Oh yeah, sometimes well meaning tire workshop workers will on their own accord swap out the plastic ones with metallic ones as a free value added service. Check for those and tell them thanks but no thanks.
 
Cheers!

If your car comes with TPMS, did you notice the cheapo looking grey plastic tire valve caps? So unbecoming of a premium conti brand to penny pinch and gave you cheap plastic valve covers, while other brands are running around with shiny metal caps? 
It's pretty cheap and at most a couple of dollars to change to metal ones but DON'T!! 
 
MB have very good reason to be "cheapo". The TPMS air valve are made from special metallic alloy and the commonly available metal air valve caps will corrode the contact surface rapidly, leading to the caps being fused to the valve threads. Once that happens, the only way to open the valve is to bring to tireshop where they will need to replace that valve. And TPMS valves comes in 1 whole unit with the sensors attached (at least for MB version) 
 
So, save that few dollars and leave the plastic ones on and potentially save yourself a few hundreds. 
Oh yeah, sometimes well meaning tire workshop workers will on their own accord swap out the plastic ones with metallic ones as a free value added service. Check for those and tell them thanks but no thanks.
 
Cheers!  

 

 
Supporting evidence:
 
https://www.thoughtco.com/achey-breakey-parts-tpms-and-corrosion-3234362
 

Achey Breakey Parts: TPMS And Corrosion
by Sean Phillips
Updated April 23, 2017


It is not seriously in doubt that TPMS sensors are generally a good safety system. It's known that they have prevented many blowouts and potential injuries caused by loss of pressure. They've also saved millions of gallons of gas from mileage-draining under pressured tires.
But boy do they also cause some major headaches for owners and installers alike. Of the many headaches commonly associated with TPMS monitors, clearly, the achiest and breakiest is the valve stems.
 
First-generation monitors especially, are not only showing the effects of age, but of some rather thoughtless design. Because so many of these sensors are a one-piece design, with the metal valve stem built into the sensor, any damage to the relatively cheap valve stem can make the expensive sensor simply useless.
And these metal valve stems do corrode and break far too easily. Valve stems on TPMS monitors can corrode for a number of different reasons. Knowing these reasons and how to prevent them can mean the difference between happy driving and disaster.PROBLEM: METAL VALVE CAPSWhile the bright and shiny chrome plated or metal valve caps that you see everywhere are often a nice effect compared to dull black plastic caps, when it comes to TPMS stems, they're a clear and present danger. Metal caps can easily cause corrosion on the threads of TPMS stems as well as beginning to corrode themselves.
 
The result is all too often that the cap will rust-weld itself to the stem, leading to outcomes from the cap simply seizing when a technician tries to remove it, to cross threading issues, or even having the stem break off entirely. When the valve stem is a nonremovable part of the TPMS monitor, this goes from being a minor issue to a critical and often expensive problem.
 SOLUTION: RUBBER VALVE CAPSIt's simple: Do not ever put metal valve caps on your TPMS valve stems. Black plastic or rubber caps may be dull and boring, but boring can be good. Having your expensive monitors turned to junk by corrosion is excitement you don't need. As Barry Steinberg from Direct Tire told me, “Initially they were putting out a lot of metal caps on these metal valve stems and they were seizing and cracking and breaking. But ever since they've all gone to rubber valve caps we've seen a lot less of that.”PROBLEM: BRASS VALVE CORESInside every valve stem is a part called the valve core. It's the part that you press down on to let air out of your tires, and it can also be unscrewed and removed with a special tool to let air out of the tires really fast. Most of the rubber snap-in valve stems out there use valve cores made of brass. Because TPMS metal valve stems are usually aluminum, they cannot use brass cores. The reason is that brass will react to the aluminum and cause the core to weld itself to the stem, making it impossible to remove. The absurdity of the situation is clear – an untrained tire tech, or just one who is not paying attention that day, can cause the destruction of a hundred-dollar TPMS sensor by installing the wrong fifty-cent valve core.SOLUTION: NICKEL-COATED VALVE CORESThe only type of valve cores that can be used in TPMS sensors are the specialized nickel-coated cores that are specifically designed to go in the valve stems. It's pretty easy to tell the difference, as the brass valve cores are, well, brass-colored, and nickel cores are silver. It's an easy and important check to remove your valve caps after any work has been done and make sure that yours are silver. If they're not, have them replaced as soon as possible. The nickel-coated cores also need to be replaced with new ones every time they are removed, as the coating is thin and can wear off simply from the action of threading and removing them, which will expose the brass under the coating.PROBLEM: AIR, WATER, AND SALTThe last reason that TPMS valve stems corrode is simply unavoidable.
Stems are exposed to the air, they get wet, and especially in winter conditions, they get exposed to road salt and salt water. Corrosion is just a fact of life when it comes to metal parts, and valve stems are exposed every minute of the day. Collet nuts, the parts that screw down over the valve stem to tighten the whole assembly against the valve stem hole are especially vulnerable to the same kind of corrosion that can cause a valve cap or valve core to seize. Horror stories abound of collet nuts seizing, valve stems breaking at the slightest pressure applied by tire techs trying to remove them, and even of stems breaking off while the vehicle is in motion.SOLUTION: PROPER MAINTENANCEThe only solution to environmental corrosion is constant vigilance, mostly in the form of service packs. Service packs are small packets that tire dealers and installers keep with all the tiny parts and widgets that need to be replaced every time your tires are serviced. These packs will include:
A new nickel-coated valve core.
A new rubber or plastic valve cap.
A new set of rubber gaskets to seal the valve hole in the wheel.
A new collet nut.
Service packs, you may note, therefore cover all of the major reasons for corrosion problems I have already noted, that being the major reason they exist. By replacing each of these parts every time your tires are serviced, you keep corrosion at bay, preventing it from gaining a foothold in the cracks and crevices between all these seemingly insignificant little parts. This is why the service packs are so important, why responsible installers will always replace them, and why you should always resist the temptation to save the small fee that they will have to charge you for doing so.
There is also a much more permanent, if somewhat more expensive way of solving TPMS corrosion problems, which is to replace your first-generation TPMS sensors with second-generation aftermarket sensors. Most aftermarket sensors now use a removable snap-in rubber valve stem that not only completely avoids most corrosion problems, but can be easily and cheaply replaced if it is damaged.
This is an especially good option to look at if your sensors are more than 6 years old, as the batteries on TPMS sensors are rated to last about 6-7 years, and cannot be replaced. That's another headache entirely.

Different models of cars have different premiums and varies across insurers. My GLC Coupe insurance is lower than my CLA Shooting Brake. This totally doesn't make sense since GLC Coupe value is higher than CLA Shooting Brake, but that's their premium table.

My personal preference in terms of new car insurance. 
 
1st year just get from the AD to save the hassle of removing rebate/service credits if you choose a cheaper outside insurance. Most important is that the AD linked insurance is definitely going to allow repairs by AD. This is important for warranty preservation. 
 
2nd to 3rd year (assuming 3yr warranty), I will get insurance broker to do the leg work and present to me a quote for the cheapest 2 quote they can find for comprehensive and return to AD for repairs. 
 
4th year onwards (out of warranty) , I will get the broker to quote me for comprehensive but only insurance co designated workshops. No point paying more for going back to AD repairs since out of warranty.
C&C & AIG now improve the cover - the new for old car replacement in the event of total loss now for the first 3 yrs.

Each time you crank your engine, you are using up your battery charge.
 
Frequent short trips will not have enough time for the battery to fully charge.

So your situation is a perfect storm brewing.

Question bros:If you swop out the RFTs for normal ones, eg PSS / PS4s, do you still follow the same tire pressure?Eg if the suggested pressure is 260, do you still follow what's on the inside of the fuel lid?

Question bros:
If you swop out the RFTs for normal ones, eg PSS / PS4s, do you still follow the same tire pressure?
Eg if the suggested pressure is 260, do you still follow what's on the inside of the fuel lid?

 
What's important is the load index.
 
If new tyre has lower load index, pump higher than 260.
 
If new tyre has higher load index, pump lower than 260.
 
This applies to all tyre.
 
Look up to Tyre pressure thread.

I am not an old bird Merc owner. But I did a research on this and also asked around in a Merc group. my humble conclusion is that the smell comes from the condensation of the aircon. Somehow the design of the aircon traps the condensation within the piping. After awhile the dampness breeds bacteria/fungi which give off the foul smell. Most people advise to change the aircon filter every servicing. Seems to affect B, C and E.

YMMV of course :)

With a drag coefficient (Cd) value of 0.23, the CLA sets a new benchmark – both within the Mercedes-Benz model range and among all production vehicles. The drag area, Cd x A – which is crucial to aerodynamic resistance – also leads the field, at 0.51 m². This record figure is undercut still further by the CLA 180 BlueEFFICIENCY Edition, which will be launched in June 2013. In this case the Cd figure is 0.22, while in terms of wind resistance the four-door coupé manages to breach another magic barrier: the figure here is just 0.49 m².

The good air flow characteristics, which are a major contributory factor to the vehicle’s low fuel consumption in everyday conditions, result from numerous aerodynamic optimization measures. These include the following features:
large diffusor cover
aero baffles
optimized rear muffler
aero covers for spring links
cover for rear axle subframe
optimized main cover
slotted wheel house liner
optimized lower stiffener
engine cover
demand controlled cooling air, using adjustable radiator shutter
optimized front apron
large area of underbody paneling and additional cladding in the center rear axle area
serrated wheel spoilers at the front and rear wheels
slotted wheel arch linings
low A-pillar shoulder
aerodynamically optimized exterior mirror housings
aerodynamically optimized rear end design (flush sitting boot lid and fins in tail lights)
aerodynamically optimized rear silencer with downstream diffuser
wheels and tires with low air resistance

Thanks

yes the pre face-lifted version.
 
Paiseh for the vagueness  , what i mean is , how is the DCT gearbox , is it much more robust than VW DSG or Ford Powershift ? Any complains on this ride that potential buyer should be aware of  (mechanically and electrically)
 
Thanks

Well bro, if you check out the local and foreign forums, you will find the discussions are quite short on complaints, and compared to many other brands, you find less trouble-shooting posts, less posts on 'why doesn't this work, why does this rattle, or why did this fail'..
 
Batteries still die - I think that's user dependant, and some panels are still not as well made as the old W214 E class or old S Class. But it's made in Germany, and the DCT is a wet one, used since 2011 in many MFA based cars.
 
So what my rep said is that the steering wheel may peel if you use creams, and the seat belt area is a bit flimsy, and I found the panel alignment as well as the plastic used in the lower sections to be a bit disappointing, but otherwise, it's been a fun year. But I am an new owner, so bring a pro along and see. Google and you will know what I mean on the scarcity of complaints. 
 
Do note the DCT is smoother in the post facelift models, and the ride is also better. The newer ones also come with the LED headlamps and a nicer display.

New naming convention?
https://www.autoblog.com/2018/02/01/mercedes-trademark-new-names-numbers/
 

 
 
"You see, you can tell the difference between a regular Mercedes and an AMG model because the Benz has three numbers with a zero on the end, while the AMG has only two numbers and no zero."That simple equation has made it easy to help people tell regular Benzes apart from their amped up brethren (and from the fake AMG-badged poseurs running around). Alas, it looks like that might be coming to an end. AutoGuide has spotted that Mercedeshas trademarked a new naming convention in Canada and other markets.Essentially, regular-series Mercedes will continue to end in a zero, but there will only be two numbers. AMG will also have two numbers, but those will all end in "3." Applications include A 40, CLA 40, SLC 40, SLC 50 and GLE 50 in Canada, along with CLA 53, G73 and S73. Yes, "73," which would be the new range-topper, probably with AMG's new performance hybridpowertrain.It's important to keep two things in mind. First, Mercedes models are now specified as -Benz, -AMG and -Maybach, meaning you'd be looking at a Mercedes-Benz CLA 40 and Mercedes-AMG CLA 53, for instance. And second, having three numbers no longer serves a purpose since those numbers no longer correspond with engine output in any way.There's no such evidence of a similar application made in the United States, but if this is the way of the Benz future, it's hard to imagine Mercedes doing something different here (although Audi is doing just that).

For absolute VFM the Audi A4 is a lot of metal for a conti car.
Good gearbox - wet clutch
 
The Mercs you refer to have a higher badge factor, but the cabin of the C Class is actually smaller than a Corolla.. which is about half the price
 
Volvos esp the older Belgium / Swedish ones are well made, safe and solid. I haven't driven the newer ones so I can't comment. But the cost of repair and maintenance is even higher than Mercs.
 
There are so many Mercs on the road, so numerous workshops will know how to service them, and their costs are lower. You can even do it across the causeway too!
 
Mercs aren't that expensive relative to the other brands. But at C&C, a Service A costs $500 or so for the CLA, so you need to get lots of service credits.
 
The BMW X1 is a spacious, high riding car based on a common platform with the Mini, and drives well. There aren't enough examples around long enough to tell how reliable or well made they are yet. Or you could sell after the warranty is over.
 
Consider how many old Mercs are still running, and not just those old W124 but even W204 C Class examples are there and compare that to the other brands and you get an idea.. The mechanicals are usually very solid, electronics are present, so if you want something basic, Toyotas are well known for that.
Even the other makes from Asian are now covered with electronics.
 
The Toyota Harrier is a good car if you like the SUV form factor ...
The Q2 is quite overpriced IMO and this as well as the Q3 are using lower level engines unless you buy the 1.4T..
 
An alternative to the GLA is the Infinity Q30. Cheaper and almost the same car.

Wow, thanks for the thorough explanation.  You brought up an important point on servicing costs.  I didn't know the costs of servicing for Volvo is higher than the other conti brands.  I only heard that Mercedes Benz (MB) had the highest servicing costs, from some of the ex-MB owners I spoke to.  I was told the basic cost for a regular servicing at Cycle & Carriage (C&C) was $1,060.  For the more major servicing, it could go up to nearly $2,000.

You need to be prepared, But...
The service is done annually, and if you add up the cost at Asian Car ADs, it's not that cheap either.
Some may scrimp and only do basic oil changes, so they baulk at even the costs that Honda or Toyota charge. I did my service for my FD at Honda throughout it's life, and it can come up to 800-1500 per year. So in comparison my bread van's service isn't that bad. 
The service credits cover most of the costs for the first three to four years..

Hi Bro, I will give u my feedback based on my experience after driving thr B180 for one year plus.
 
1. There are two batteries in the car. One main battery at the engine compartment and one side battery at the glove compartment area. The side battery is used for start stop purpose.
 
2. The start stop is always working but u can turn it off manually using a button on the center console or u programmed in individual mode and turn off the start stop function. If u leave it on, it is working unless it is not meeting certain condition and u will see it on the dashboard display with a A circle around it. There are a few conditions which will affect the start stop. I know one of them is the air con. If it is not reaching the temperature u set, the start stop will cut off. So if u always blast your air con, most likely your start stop will always cut off.
 
3. On your aircon setting, i have not try c180. But for my B180, i normally set to fan at 1, and temp at 22 deg and it is blowing cold air like mad. But sometime i need to set to fan at 2 to cool down fast. I thought the solar film is doing quite a good job.
 
4, Sound proofing, again based on my B180 it is still ok. Not so loud compared to my previous jap car.maybe the roof of B180 is also quite high compared to C class. So it might not sound so loud as your ears are futher away. Joking.
 
5. Jerking gear shifting at low rev is a common thing for dual clutch car. My B180 also got the same problem. Just need to get use to it. The other thing i encounter is sometime the car will just rev up suddenly and i need to jam the brake.
 
If u chane to sports mode, it will drink petrol like water. That is my expereince but it is very responsive. The suspension will be harder too. But u can set to individual setting and set differrnt mode for the engine and suspension. This is what i do and csn also turn on and off the start stop to your liking.

No way the suspension will have any change unless your car is optionally equipped with airmatic.

I was unlucky enough to be hit at the back of W212 while stationery, by a taxi. First inspection after the crash, my rear bumper was cracked, under-tray cracked, exhaust mounting bent. The taxi was under emergency brake, and his nose dived under my car. 
 
My first impression, was my car damage was light. No damage to the boot lid, nor flanks. The Sonata taxi looked worse with buckled bonnet, broken headlights and broken radiator. I successfully claimed agains the taxi's insurance. The repairs were done at C&C.
 
Only at the repairs did I find out that under the bumper of Mercs, BMW and Jags, is a steel reinforcement bar to protect the rear from a heavy collision. This bar was the reason why the boot damage was limited. The bar took the brunt of the impact and deformed as designed, absorbing the force. The bar had to be replaced, but the cost is a lot lower than replacing the whole boot lid and side panels, which would have been necessary had the reinforcement bar not been there.
 
This incident shows that the top European cars have even rear passenger safety from rear collision on their minds. Nice to know this.

Mazda 3 also got the metal bar at the bumper I don't think it's a uncommon feature

Below is the results of real experiment to bust the myth on the so called savings of AUTO-START-STOP
 
AUTO-START-STOP ALWAYS OFF, comfort mode: 30,000 km at 13.9km/L FC* 
AUTO-START-STOP ALWAYS ON, comfort mode: 10,000 km at 14.4km/L FC* [And even going to the extent of turning OFF the air-con with the just hte fan on at traffic light so that I can maintain the extend OFF mode for > 30 seconds.]
 
*FC calculated from mileage clocked divide by actual petrol pumped (as per petrol station receipt) 
*Based on daily mileage of 100km/day with 80km expressway + 20km non-expressway.
 
 
Assuming 40,000km mileage clocked over 400 days (at 100km/day) & RON98 $2.60/Litre:
 
a) Petrol Spend = 40,000km / 13.9 * $2.60/L = $7,498 in 400 days 
b) Petrol Spend = 40,000km / 14.4 * $2.60/L= $7,210 in 400 Days
 
Savings in petrol spend = $7498-$7210 = $288 savings in 400 days
=> Savings $0.22/day or  $22/month.
 
My conclusion: AUTO START-STOP do save some small quantity of petrol.

Hi all, wondering if anyone can advise. 
 
Went down to C&C merc showroom and SE offered 10K OT + further 10K discount. However, he said loan has to be based on list price and rebate is given in the form of reduced cash outlay for downpayment. 
 
Is this standard practice?
 
Thanks in advance!

As far as I know, this what most AD with high list price will do.
List price allows them to keep the RRP, the effective price remove the 'freebies' like service credits & the net price is what you pay in the end.
High list price means you can loan more & the AD make more.
It also allows you to buy at much lower price to feel shiok & earlier buyers also won't heart pain the price drop so much.
PS - I still prefer a more transparent pricing than this practice.

https://www.express.co.uk/life-style/cars/973108/Mercedes-Benz-diesel-cars-C-Class-GLC-Vito-emissions-defeat-devices
 
Diesel-gate Mercedes Style

some more info on the exact form of the "cheating"
 

 
Exact details of the issue are yet to be revealed, but it's thought it relates to the AdBlue system. AdBlue is an additive injected into the Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) filter to reduce emissions. But Mercedes software potentially reduces the quantity of AdBlue after a set period of time, improving performance and fuel economy but increasing harmful nitrous oxide (NOx) emissions.
 
The so-called "thermal switch" is set at a particular temperature. Carmakers that use this system argue it's part of ensuring longevity rather than an attempt to cheat.

I installed a higher grade Huper 15-16 years back, cost me above $1k. After 10 years it started to degrade, some delamination and some parts turned cloudy. Heat rejection was good though. I had also installed V-Cool before but did not keep that car for 10 years. My C&C W211's film lasted fine for 10 years except I was unhappy because the film was uneven when it goes over the rear defogger and the view was slightly blurred. This issue might be solved for the newer models. I will just take the free film.
The customised fit Laser shades work well for me. IMO a better buy than trying to upgrade the free solar film..

Took my GLC up the NSHW recently, sharing observation on the behaviour of the 9G-tronic at higher than 90kph.
 
When in Eco mode, once it hits above 100-105kph or so, the gear will shift from 8th to 9th gear. And with the shift, the rpm will drop from 2++k  to 1.6k. I guess this is where the fuel saving will come in when you are cruising at such speed and especially if you are intending to be in cruise control anyway.

Alot of times, I do not have the opportunity to sieve left because of back to back slow vehicles in the left lane, so I will usually step on my accelerator to get ahead to filter left when safe. Nobody anywhere in the world who buys a Mercedes Benz has any doubt what the three-pointed star represents. Especially in Singapore. 
 
Anyone who says otherwise is either attempting false humility or trying to deceive oneself. 
 
A Mercedes is not really high class because it’s pricing is inflated in Singapore. No Mercedes is Low class either because of the same inflated pricing in Singapore. 
 
However, there are models that are made with certain engine pairings in mind. They are engineered to be optimised for certain functions and power output to give the distinctive Mercedes Benz ride. It has a reputation to live up to. 
 
Due to the pricing in Singapore and our strange tax laws, certain models with lower output and prices become popular here. These models make some compromises in terms of functions, power, ride comfort etc based on a slider that optimises on what is acceptable between price, badge, reputation and popularity. 
 
That is why I prefer to classify the models into “Normal” classes and “Compromise” classes.

I always find it amusing to find questions of minimum RON in premium conti threads. 
 
If the amount saved  from using 95 instead of 98 is significant enough to make the person bother, then that really begs the question if a premium conti is really for the person.
 
I said this many times in MCF,  modern  cars with decent performance will have a couple of fuel maps in their Ecu. The car will default to most advanced ignition timing until it detects detonation and it will retard the timing using a lower map till it finds the optimum performance for the fuel you gives it.
 
You give it RON 98, it will give you RON 98 performance. You give it RON 95 it will give you RON95 performance. If you drive sedately.all the time, just use RON 95. If you are a keen driver, only RON 98 will do. Just because you cannot discern the difference in performance because you drive sedately anyway does not meant RON98 is waste of money for people who utilize it better than you.

All new Mercedes, with the exception of AMG models, are optimized to run at Ron95.  If it's an AMG, pump 98.  Else, pump 95.  You get no benefit pumping 98 into a non-AMG unit unless you have some tunes going under the hood.  Or you want to show-off to the pretty station cashier. Just follow what your fuel cap says. 
 
 
If you are still unsure, check out the fuel recommended for your models here.
 
  https://www.mercedes-benz.com.hk/content/hongkong/mpc/mpc_hongkong_website/enng/home_mpc/passengercars/home/servicesandaccessories/services_online/interactive_manual.html

Difference in parts quality these days are not that much difference given global sourcing. Rarely an auto maker makes their own components. Air filter made by hengst, Mann, Mahler are all approved vendors to Daimler. 
 
These manufacturers also supply to other car makers worldwide. Quite some are still hesistant to use oem parts. I have seen an orig Merc air filter vs a Mann filter. The only diff is Mercedes part number printed on it.
 
Also just FYI to all.C&C does not carry all the parts in their store, they just like all other stockist order from the Daimler warehouse in Singapore which also supplies parts regionally. C&C like everyone else is but a mere authorized distributor. 
 
Ordering parts from stockist is usually cheaper and sometimes even faster that getting from C&C.

History of Rule 78
* The earliest official use of the Rule of 78s to calculate the unearned portion of a loan’s finance charge was in Indiana in 1935. Most loans then were for small amounts at low interest rates for short period like 12 months during the pre-computer era.
* The number 78 is actually the sum of 1 to 12 (1+2+3…..+11+12 = 78).
* Assuming a 12 month loan with interest of $1,000,
1st month – 12/78 x $1,000 = $153.85 will be your payment on this interest,
2nd month – 11/78 x $1,000 = $141.02 will be your 2nd month payment on this interest
12th month – 1/78 x $1,000 = $12.82 to be your 12th months payment on this interest.
 
http://thefinance.sg/2009/06/20/the-perils-of-rule-78/

Since I’m an advocate of sharing I shall repost what I sent to the 2 guys.  
 
quite a few merc workshops around.
 
i have personally tried the following, for my current car.
 
1. MB auto, amk autopoint.
quite good. Eric is a good mech. not that cheap but decent work.
 
2. Auto spritze, Kim Chuan Terrace.
My current workshop. quite some mechanics to work on your car. very knowledgeable on mercs and VW. reasonable pricing but can be a little ex for some items.
 
3. R2D, Woodlands.
More of a BMW workshop. spent 1 year with them. Rodney is detailed. But in the end i decided not to go cause
a. too far from my place at Siglap.
b. odd opening hours 1-10pm. good in the sense that you can drop by at night to get stuff fixed, but the problem is only 4hrs from 1-5pm to work with parts suppliers, thus sometimes the parts get delayed till the next day. meaning i send in the car at 1pm, but the time they strip out the parts and find out what is wrong, sometimes the part shop close for the day and then need to wait till the next day to get the parts.
c. reasonable pricing.
 
4. Kam Motor, 189 Tanjong Katong
Visited them only once to change alternator as Auto spritze was closed for CNY holidays. only one hoist.as its is a small workshop at the back of the Esso station. cars will be worked on in the sun and sometimes rain. I don't really like it.
Very decent pricing. good thing is that the shop is near civilization. easy to get out from or hang out at the mall should the job just take 1-2hours.
 
 
When i had an Old old merc.
 
1. MB auto
2. MB Auto (JB), same name but different shop.
3. Balmoral Auto
 
Merc shops i went to chit chat but never did anything
 
1. Carewell auto, Sin Ming
2. Nam Sing, AMK autopoint
Also those who are looking for owners who hands on, it will be both MB AUTO and R2D.

Just an update on my 7G to 9G trade-in through AD that was signed a few months back.  Have collected my new ride a few weeks ago and it is good.  The 9G certainly feels smoother during gear change.  The rest of the car is pretty much the same. The multimedia software seems to have been updated and responds more quickly than my 7G.  The sound system seems better too.  The Thinkware cameras are user friendly as you can access the car cam videos through an app using the camera wifi.  The camera comes with lane departure and forward collision warning systems  but I turned it off as the camera's sensitivity is higher than the car's and I was getting lots of warning sounds which was pretty irritating after a while.  
 
Some follow-up details on the deal in case you may be offered similar trade-in offer.
 
I managed to increase my trade-in price to 151k from 150k.  This package includes the Car Essentials Plus which adds front and rear brake pads, aircon filter and chemical wash, battery replacements on top of 4x PPS, interior wash, windscreen polish, etc..  They threw in the integrated Garmin GPS for free. I still haven't gotten around to using it much. The good part is that it is touchscreen operated. 
 
I requested for a waiver of early repayment penalty fee on my HP loan with MBFS since new loan is with them too, which my SE said could be done but they need to put in request before the old loan has been paid off. I think it helped that I was using MBFS - I doubt if it can be done if your loan is with a bank. The amount was a few hundred bucks.  I still had to pay the admin fee and some related taxes. So no cash outflow as the new loan covered balance of my old loan and deposit on new car plus a few k left over. Of course, the loan repayment starts all over again! 
 
Unexpected bonus was my insurance rebate on the 7G.  It does not factor in $500 rebate that was given by AD when I renewed the policy in March for $800+ (after $500 rebate).  The pro-rated rebate I received was $800+ too as it is based on actual policy premium of $1300+.  
 
After signing the deal in May, I thought AD would give me a lower price COE when cat B dropped to $32k but they were on the up and up and gave me a $38k May COE which means their margin on my 9G is lower than their margin on my previous 7G.  
 
Overall, I am very pleased with this deal. It would not surprise me to see more of these deals coming out in the months ahead as I think they have targets to meet so hope my points above can help. Gotta thank you guys for your advice and inputs in clarifying my thoughts on this deal.  BTW, SE told me that they will take a big hit on my 7G in the 2nd hand market!

Just an update on my 7G to 9G trade-in through AD that was signed a few months back.  Have collected my new ride a few weeks ago and it is good.  The 9G certainly feels smoother during gear change.  The rest of the car is pretty much the same. The multimedia software seems to have been updated and responds more quickly than my 7G.  The sound system seems better too.  The Thinkware cameras are user friendly as you can access the car cam videos through an app using the camera wifi.  The camera comes with lane departure and forward collision warning systems  but I turned it off as the camera's sensitivity is higher than the car's and I was getting lots of warning sounds which was pretty irritating after a while.  
 
 
Some follow-up details on the deal in case you may be offered similar trade-in offer.
 
I managed to increase my trade-in price to 151k from 150k.  This package includes the Car Essentials Plus which adds front and rear brake pads, aircon filter and chemical wash, battery replacements on top of 4x PPS, interior wash, windscreen polish, etc..  They threw in the integrated Garmin GPS for free. I still haven't gotten around to using it much. The good part is that it is touchscreen operated. 
 
I requested for a waiver of early repayment penalty fee on my HP loan with MBFS since new loan is with them too, which my SE said could be done but they need to put in request before the old loan has been paid off. I think it helped that I was using MBFS - I doubt if it can be done if your loan is with a bank. The amount was a few hundred bucks.  I still had to pay the admin fee and some related taxes. So no cash outflow as the new loan covered balance of my old loan and deposit on new car plus a few k left over. Of course, the loan repayment starts all over again! 
 
Unexpected bonus was my insurance rebate on the 7G.  It does not factor in $500 rebate that was given by AD when I renewed the policy in March for $800+ (after $500 rebate).  The pro-rated rebate I received was $800+ too as it is based on actual policy premium of $1300+.  
 
After signing the deal in May, I thought AD would give me a lower price COE when cat B dropped to $32k but they were on the up and up and gave me a $38k May COE which means their margin on my 9G is lower than their margin on my previous 7G.  
 
Overall, I am very pleased with this deal. It would not surprise me to see more of these deals coming out in the months ahead as I think they have targets to meet so hope my points above can help. Gotta thank you guys for your advice and inputs in clarifying my thoughts on this deal.  BTW, SE told me that they will take a big hit on my 7G in the 2nd hand market!

I will use what I've posted previously to calculate, see if everyone agrees: 
 
Assuming paper value of both cars is the same = 20k
Your current car annual dep is 220k - 20k/10  = 20k dep/yr 
New car depreciation is = 21.5k dep/yr, therefore new car cost = 21.5 * 10 + 20k = 235k
 
Your depreciation for that 3.5yrs after trade in = 220k - 144k   = 76k
 
Total dep for your new car over 10yrs + Dep of old car over 3.5yrs = (235k + 76k)/ 13.5 = 23k dep/yr
 
So:
20k dep/yr if you drive for 10yrs in your current car
VS 
23k dep/yr if you trade in your car ​+ the new car price is 235k
 
To me all the service credits shouldn't be computed as part of the "bleeding" cost cause that's one could argue that you "extended" your loans again, since you got them the first time you bought ur current car. I felt that it is the sales tactic to convince you that its worth it.
 
Using this one can calculate what is the break even point to switch, to "bleed" less compare to current car.

How to use Paddle Shift (for benefit of rest of mercedes owners):
 
- Left paddle: single tap to down shift 1 gear. double taps to downshift 2 gears.
The gear indicator will change from D to M (manual) and the current gear number will be shown. It stay in this mode till it times out if no further input to manually up or downshift.
 
- Right paddle: single tap to up shift 1 gear. double taps to upshift 2 gears and so on. The gear indicator will change from D to M (manual) and the current gear number will be shown. It stay in this mode till it times out if no further input to manually up or downshift.
 
*Tip:  tap and hold the right paddle to revert to full auto mode (D) at any point during the (M) mode. 
I use this neat feature quite often.
 
Eg. when approaching a tight curve with no traffic around, I will use the left paddle shift to downshift 1-2 gears such that the tachometer hovers around 3K RPM ( My power band drops off after 4K RPM), this will engine brake the car and allow me to go round the curve without braking and once pass the apex, i will step in on my accelerator to power out of the curve. While stepping in on the accelerator, I will press and hold the right paddle to hand over the gears control to the 9G-tronic, that way as the car accelerate from the curve, the AT can automatically up shift optimally without me having to bother when to upshift.

Let me clarify a few of your misinformation.
 
1. There is no practical situation on the road to need to go one gear higher manually from full auto (D). So why would anyone want to press the + paddle shift to activate the (M) mode? Just down gear immediately already.
 
Edit: I have never even attempted to upshift from (D) mode, so cannot say for sure if (M) can be activate. Will try this evening and update here later.
 
2. Pressing and holding the + is to change from (M) to (D) mode. Engine no need run in.
 
The rest of the car needs run in what.

Engine and transmission don't need running in. 
 
Brand new tires need proper run in.
 
Brake pads need proper bedding in to the rotors.

Engine no need run in.
 
The rest of the car needs run in what.
Every things need to b run in especially all moving parts.Engine ,transmission ,brakes etc etc
I even recommend heat cycle run in.
The best way is start it in the morning,warm it up for a while,drive to yr usual b/fast haunt & let it cool down,later continue yr journey to the office & park it.
After work,warm it up,drive up to any of those watering hole & let all rotating parts to cool off than head back home for a final shut down.
Dis expansion & contraction will aids in a complete run in.
Nowadays the engine come in with their own run in oil to assist in their run in process.

I used to pump my tires when I am on the way home
 
pumped higher pressure than what I want
 
left it overnight
 
tomorrow morning release the air to the correct pressure

There can never be 100% nitrogen in the tyre.
 
When the wheel is mounted to the rim, air is already inside. 
 
Unless the tyre shop vacuums out all the air and then pumps nitrogen inside, then "got count".
 
Else, pumping nitrogen in like that seems 多此一举 to me.
 
If it's free, and it's on the way a short distance (1.6km) away, why not.
 
But to specially drive down just to pump (and when your tyre is hot), nah not for me.
 
Btw tyre pressures expand 20-30 kpa during driving. I've never seen it expand 50kpa unless it's on the track.

One of the BS that C&C salesman and saleswoman are trained to dish out is this "effective price".  Its basically deducting from the discounted list price (which is basically the price they really wish to sell) with all the "service credit" lah, "insurance support" lah, simi "overtrade" lah..   if we just zoomed into the "service credit" alone, that item is basically an upfront payment by the BUYER to facilitate merciless carrot chopping..  BUT C&C DEDUCT that amount from the "discounted list" and termed the resultant number as "effective price".
 
Allow me to use an extreme example to illustrate how stupid is this BS...
-  say the GLC Coupe is 238k LIST.
-  discounted list let's say it is 228k
-  if C&C say "Service Credit" is 200k, then they can proudly declare that the "effective price" is only 28k.  
 
That's basically catching a chicken by the neck and swing until the chicken is confused and the head dropped off.

Car loans are not like property loans. For most car loans, all the interests for the loan period (e.g. 10 years) is already added in upfront. So there is little point in redeeming any car loans. So the worst possible course of action is to take a 10-year car loan. The shorter the better.

If u have money sitting in the Bank earning 1%, it makes sense to redeem. 7/8 rule is unfair but it is still a rebate. The maths is complicated but if u sit down and compute, there is still some savings for early prepayment. Most people i know redeem after 1 year.

 
https://www.sgcarmart.com/news/writeup.php?AID=61
 
The maths is not too complicated, I have done it before.
Based on "their" initial way of interest calculation, the outstanding remaining interest is actually $5000 (for the example given). But they will only rebate you $2688.52. So effectively you are paying $2311.48 worth of interest for absolutely nothing if you redeem the loan early. Of course you did "save" $2688.52. If you have $30,000 in the bank at 1% interest, you would only get about $1,000 worth of interest. But in the first place, you should have used that $30,000 to reduce the car loan, which is the point of my post. 
Also, instead of redeeming the car loan and getting cheated by the rule of 78, you may be better off using the money to buy say the F&N Bonds. Of course the bond may also default.

Everyone knows to take less loan if you have cash in the bank earning 1% p.a. interest versus 5-6% pa effective HP financing rate.  A lot of us took loan becoz it is tied to service credit and/ or some other freebies, so the question is whether it is worthwhile to prepay once the freebies are in the bag and there is no longer an outright prepayment penalty.   5-6% p.a. loan is very expensive to keep. 
Like you said it yourself, if your money is idling away at 1% interest and you use it to pay down a 5-6% loan, even with 7/8 rule, you will still save.

Hi, seeking help here on behalf of my colleague who owns a Mercedes S350.
 
She complains of this beeping sound coming from her in car camera. One long beep followed by 2 short ones. The factory supplied unit appears to be a Logon JS400, which I am not familiar with. I read the manual and am more confused.
 
I saw only one solid green light at the box mounted below the glove compartment. The other light is not lighted. Retrieving the microSD card, I saw a list of avi files but all are front camera videos. There is a PC player file in the card but no Mac version (I only have Macbook). Both front and back cameras have a red light.
 
1. Is there a problem with the camera? Back camera not writing to SD card?
2. How to reset the system?
3. Where can I retrieve the back camera videos?
4. How to turn on/off the sound recording?
5. Is there a Mac version of the PC reader?
 
Thanks in advance and apologies if some of the questions have already been asked and answered.
Hi @kstoh, 
I faced the same problem as your friend before and after going to meet up with tomogroup mechanic, I was told that every 1-2 months, you will have to take out the MicroSD card to have it formatted. I was told that it is due to the storage full and overwriting of the files that caused it to have error. When u hear the beeping sound, u will see that the camera red LED indicator will go off. And the next time u hear the beep, it will light up again, indicating that it has restarted. 
 
You have to go to www.thetomogroup.com to download their Logon PC Viewer (which has only the PC version). I have to use my old PC laptop with a SD card reader to load it and format the card as my current laptops are Mac.
 
For me, after formatting the MicroSD card and then reinserting back in, the problem will be gone. However, u got to do it every 1-2 months when it happens again. Remember to back up any footages that are important before formatting.
 
You can drop a mail to Matthew if you want to find out more or need further clarification at: matthew.ng@tomocse.com.sg
 
Hope this helps.  Cheers!

i have share my thoughts in the C class chat and i think members should have another point of view
 
this post is definitely written by a SE (Sale Executive , or a complete Newbie whose name is Robert that kena Carrot)
 
simple, cos the post left out a few key factors
 
1) Firstly the promo Pohtk received is very standard nothing special at all to be honest,
anyone walk in the doors of Cycle will receive the same package 
 
the Merc Festiva (22-24 Mar) also offer 12K OT, 6K Service Credits & COE Rebate at 39K , option 2-7 (is standard)
 
2) what is missing is that, Pohtk did not mention (assume that he does not know ) is the trade in price
 
he has to sell a car to enjoy OT, what was he driving prior? what is the price quoted by RA ?
was it a "fair price"?
 
the trade in price after the SE / Republic Auto can be Neg again, (if you do your homework and know the actual sale price, but lets be fair to Republic auto they do need to make 2-3K off your ride for admin charges, etc)
 
3) there is actually a "commission per car" from the SE (which i know but i cannot say, due to NDA), dun believe the SE cock story, i only earn $500 - $1000 from the sale. FAKE NEWS, that is only if you pay the car in FULL CASH. 
 
as long you take loans, decent amt, they have a good buffer. they have X amt (a few k) to play with you.
 
so Pohtk so call "good SE" didnt even bother to give him a bit of discount at all? - give him the full RRP of C klass?
 
also the loan % also fake news, it is not 60%.
the number of years can also be NEG, just ask any AMG 65 /63 owners, on average they pay $100,000 over 1 year, just to compensate and token of appreciation to their SE for the admin work. 
 
so Pohtk took the max number of years loand at 60% ?  is that your package? 
 
4) after the SE level of "discount", there is still "senior managment discount" , but that one you need to really know someone inside, either Cycle, RA or Diamler. How much they give you, is another topic
 
5) the discount given in option 4 can be via soft credits (service credits) or higher OT or outright discount.
 
6) do you know the Service credits can be converted into actual discount?
this is esp useful if you are given $8-10K service credits but you are confident that you will change car into a different brand within the next 1-2 year and will not use finish the service credits.
 
the above information is actually quite a "open secret" and any one in the auto sales industry or old birds who buy cars from AD can confirm are real. 
 
cheers!

any members who dont believe what i have said, can easily join any local Merc chat group and check for yourself.
 
if not you are most welcome to join their Merc MU and ask directly to the OLD BIRDS. They can share with you additional goodies tips.

Coe is coe, parf is parf both are unrelated. You get parf back only if you scrap before the car is 10years old from its 1st reg date.  
You can renew coe as many times within the coe 10years period, you only forfeit the previous coe paid. 
 
I have a few examples posted before.

Go petrol station, pump up all the 4x tire pressure according to the recommended pressure found at the fuel door. 
 
Reset the tire pressure sensor in your instrument cluster (if any) 
 
Monitor for the next half to 1 day see if the warning light comes back. If so means ur tire has a small leak. Just bring it to a tyre shop for them to find the leak and patch if possible. <$20 job usually.

B-class came with Silver Dynamic AGM as default battery. It is the highest grade of batteries produced by Varta and made in Germany. Simply put, Silver Dynamic AGM batteries are meant for cars with start-stop function with regenerative braking. Blue Dynamic batteries are meant for cars with start-stop function only, so is cheaper. To be fair to car owners, the AD should be forced to take in the car in exchange for a brand new one (same model or closest one, even if facelifted etc.) without any financial penalty on the owner except for the COE differential. Depreciation shouldn't factor into it as he never really got to enjoy his car - it's a lemon! It spent most of its days in the workshop.  
As for COE, depending on whether it's higher or lower, the owner should either top up or get a rebate vs what he paid for the old car. This is the only tricky part which is out of both the dealer's and customer's hands. If there were sudden price swings, that can be decisively bad for marginal buyers who may need a bridging loan for COE top up.

I think you know which guy I'm referring to with regard to the E55 lemon case. It's one of the FOCS chaps. And he definitely has deep pockets. The "trick" that the big players engage in is to keep getting the case continued so the plaintiff becomes very deeply in the hole with regard to legal fees. It's kind of a Catch-22, because a cheaper law firm may not be willing to take on a prominent AD and their high priced lawyers in the first place. So any plaintiff would be forced to engage a highly reputable law firm. And you can imagine how the fees would mount up when things keep getting delayed.
 
I'd say 50k is the *lower* limit of what one can expect to shell out without hope of recovery (and still without any guarantee of success). 
 
I hope no one mistakes my sincere realism as my being against @Lipingasia or on the side of the big players here, I'm clearly not. But the system is rigged in a sense.

Yes, I wanted to mention this but didn't want to dampen his enthusiasm or quench his hope.
 
I think you know which guy I'm referring to with regard to the E55 lemon case. It's one of the FOCS chaps. And he definitely has deep pockets. The "trick" that the big players engage in is to keep getting the case continued so the plaintiff becomes very deeply in the hole with regard to legal fees. It's kind of a Catch-22, because a cheaper law firm may not be willing to take on a prominent AD and their high priced lawyers in the first place. So any plaintiff would be forced to engage a highly reputable law firm. And you can imagine how the fees would mount up when things keep getting delayed.
 
I'd say 50k is the *lower* limit of what one can expect to shell out without hope of recovery (and still without any guarantee of success).
 
I hope no one mistakes my sincere realism as my being against @Lipingasia or on the side of the big players here, I'm clearly not. But the system is rigged in a sense.

this is my fear for TS too. We small consumers always get bullied by big players like them.
If there is a legal tussle, the company would have suffer the intangible damage, unless they can prove beyond doubts they are not responsible.

If there is a legal tussle, the company would have suffer the intangible damage, unless they can prove beyond doubts they are not responsible. 
 
Singapore adopts commonwealth law system and is largely based on reasonableness.
 
AD should demonstrate that mitigation measures such as engaging specialist have been applied to diagnose to solve the problems before they can determine the value of repair is beyond economical repair. Hence, it may not be reasonable to discharge liability without knowing the exact issue/reason.

Like to seek feedback from GLA180 owners.



	I went for test drive today at Mercedes showroom and my experience as follows:



		Cabin insulation - Road noise is apparent and engine noise can get quite loud (both idling and driving). Automated start-stop was disabled and drove mainly on comfort mode. The roar from the engine is quite bad in sports mode. 
	
	
		Bumpy ride, especially over road humps
	
	
		Acceleration seems non-linear, I had to floor the accelerator pretty hard to get the car to speed up.
	

	Was what I had experienced something that is expected? If I am correct, GLA180 is using dual clutch transmission but the acceleration seems so different from Skoda Karoq (on DCT as well). 



	To set expectations, I have been a Kimchi boy since my first car - started off with KIA Cerato and now driving a Hyundai Elantra. I am looking to change to a crossover/SUV and recently test drove Skoda Karoq.

	OK, let's say you're right. Or that the workshop is giving you reliable info. Remember that it's in the interests of any workshop or parts supplier to agree with you if you start worrying about whether this or that needs to be changed. As an example, I had my M5's DCT fluid changed for piece of mind, even though it's supposed to be a "lifetime" component according to the AD and BMW themselves. But online forums and pro mechs and worried M car owners in Singapore were all in agreement that it's a "better safe than sorry" sort of thing. The 3rd party workshop never argued with me, they were quite happy to do it, and they did a proper job, no complaints. The same sort of thing happens when people service their cars every 5k km rather than the more usual 10 to 15k interval recommended by most German manufacturers. 



	And then there are those who tell you you should change everything pre-emptively, even key fob batteries. Just in case costly "re-coding" is necessary if you let the batteries go completely dead. 



	What I'm trying to say is that in your place, I would just have let the TPMS soldier on and see how much life it had left. If it died soon thereafter, no biggie, if the replacement cost close to a grand, you wouldn't have saved much doing it with the tyre change anyway, so what did you lose? And it might have surprised you. Basic mantra: don't try to fix what ain't broken, especially for a non-critical non-wear part. 



	And if you think these bills are "atas", I don't want to scare you with the preventive maintenance I pay for my current car lol.

	Original factory TPMS sensors (integrated with air valve stem) are NEVER battery-changable, no matter what brand.



	Always have to get new ones and re-sync to TPMS controller. Lifespan is typically (I believe) 5-7years.
